Headline: JCDecaux Signs Contract With BT Payphones
Story: Edited Press Release   PARIS--JCDecaux SA (7791.FR), the number one outdoor advertising company in Europe and in the Asia-Pacific region and number two worldwide, confirmed today that JCDecaux has signed a 5-year contract (with a 5-year extension provision) with BT Payphones in the UK.   Under the contract, which was previously held by Clear Channel, JCDecaux will market the advertising space on up to 50,000 of BT's public payphones in England, Wales and Scotland under the brand name StreetTalk. The new revenue from these faces will be reported within JCDecaux UK's Billboard Division.   Jeremy Male, CEO of JCDecaux in the UK and Northern Europe, said: "StreetTalk is a product that offers clients urban penetration and is an integral part of the cityscape, delivering huge reach among younger audiences with a presence in all key city centres."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 11:47 ET (16:47 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Labopharm appoints new member to Board of Directors
Story: LAVAL, QC, Feb. 19 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ - Labopharm Inc. (TSX: DDS; NASDAQ: DDSS) today announced that Julia R. Brown has been appointed to the Company's Board of Directors and will become a member of the Human Resources and Corporate Governance Committee.     "With an extensive and diverse background in the life-sciences industry, including biotechnology, pharmaceuticals and drug delivery, as well as specific experience in pharmaceutical sales and marketing, Ms. Brown is a strong addition to our Board," said James R. Howard Tripp, President and Chief Executive Officer, Labopharm Inc. "We look forward to her guidance and counsel as we continue to pursue the global commercialization of our once-daily formulation of tramadol and build our product pipeline."     Ms. Brown serves as member of the Board of Directors of Tanox, Inc., Mediquest Therapeutics, Inc., and Rx3 Pharmaceuticals, Inc. She serves as a member of the commercial advisory board of CovX.. She also serves on the boards of the UCSD Foundation, the La Jolla Institute for Molecular Medicine, the Veteran's Medical Research Foundation, and CONNECT. She is a member of Tech Coast Angels, an organization that provides early stage financing and managerial assistance to technology and life-science entrepreneurs.     From 2000 to 2003, Ms. Brown was Executive Vice President of Amylin Pharmaceuticals, Inc. where she was responsible for commercial operations. She continues to serve as an Advisor to the CEO. Previously, she was Executive Vice President of Dura Pharmaceuticals. Prior to joining Dura, she was with Eli Lilly and Company for more that 25 years in progressively more senior roles. She served as Vice President of Lilly's subsidiary, IVAC Corporation and was General Manager of IVAC's Vital Signs business. She was Vice President of Marketing for Hybritech, another Lilly subsidiary.     Labopharm also announced that Mr. Robert Raich has retired from the Company's Board of Directors.        About Labopharm Inc.     Labopharm Inc. is an international specialty pharmaceutical company focused on the development of drugs incorporating the Company's proprietary advanced controlled-release technologies. The Company's lead product, a once-daily formulation of the analgesic tramadol, has been approved and launched in Europe and is currently under review for approval by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. For more information, please visit www.labopharm.com.     This press release contains forward-looking statements, which reflect the Corporation's current expectations regarding future events. The forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties. Actual events could differ materially from those projected herein and depend on a number of factors, including the uncertainties related to the regulatory process and the commercialization of the Corporation's products thereafter. Investors should consult the Corporation's ongoing quarterly filings and annual reports for additional information on risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements. The reader is cautioned not to rely on these forward-looking statements. The Corporation disclaims any obligation to update these forward-looking statements.    SOURCE  Labopharm Inc.       /CONTACT: At Labopharm, Mark D'Souza, Chief Financial Officer, Tel: (450) 680-0207; At The Equicom Group, Jason Hogan, Media and Investor Relations, Tel: (416) 815-0700, jhogan@equicomgroup.com; French: Eric Bouchard, Tel: (514) 844-7997, ebouchard@equicomgroup.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 07:00 ET (12:00 GMT)

Headline: : GENIVAR Income Fund Announces February Distribution>GNV.UN.T
Story: MONTREAL, Feb. 19 /CNW Telbec/ - GENIVAR Income Fund (TSX: GNV.UN) announced today that its monthly cash distribution of $0.0833 per Fund unit covering the period from February 1 to February 28, 2007, will be paid on March 15, 2007 to unitholders of record at the close of business on February 28, 2007.    GENIVAR Income Fund also announced today that a quarterly cash distribution of $0.25 per Subordinated LP Unit covering the period from October 1 to December 31, 2006, which was paid on February 15, 2007 to holders of subordinated LP Units of record at the close of business on December 31, 2006.    GENIVAR is a leading Canadian engineering services firm providing private and public sector clients with a full range of professional consulting services through all execution phases of a project including planning, design, construction and maintenance. Its clients, which are of varying sizes, fall into various market segments such as building, industrial and power, urban infrastructure, transportation and environment. GENIVAR is one of the largest engineering services firm in Canada in terms of number of employees with approximately 1,800 managers, professionals, technicians and technologists and support staff in over 30 offices in Canada and abroad.         /CONTACT: Marlene Casciaro, Director of Communications, GENIVAR, (514) 340-0046, ext. 5184     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 16:06 ET (21:06 GMT)

Headline: EMI Mulling Refinancing, Possible Disposals - Source >EMI.LN
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--EMI Group PLC (EMI.LN) is considering a range of options including refinancing its debt and possible asset disposals, a person familiar with the situation said Monday.   But this person stressed that while EMI was looking at "everything," an imminent disposal of its recorded music unit was unlikely due to antitrust restrictions.   The London-based music company, whose artists include Robbie Williams, Norah Jones and Joss Stone and which owns the rights to the back-catalog for The Beatles, has issued two profit warnings in the past two weeks, due mainly to a slump in U.S. CD sales.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 04:39 ET (09:39 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: EU Clears LBO France To Buy Concrete Producer Consolis -2-
Story: Finnish Consolis Oy was bought by Nordic investment firm Industri Kapital in 1997 and subsequently merged with French concrete company Bonna Sabla, which Industri Kapital bought last year for EUR235 million.   The enlarged company, Consolis, makes precast concrete products such as floors and walls in 100 plants across Europe. It operates mainly in the public services markets such as water and sanitation, civil engineering and urban environment.   Industri Kapital agreed to sell Consolis to LBO France early last month. Consolis employs 8,000 people and had sales of EUR1.2 billion in 2006.   The takeover was cleared under the commission's simplified procedure. This clears deals automatically after one month if no third party lodges a complaint.   -By Carolyn Henson, Dow Jones Newswires; +32 2 741 1484; carolyn.henson@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 05:28 ET (10:28 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Steelworkers Call On CIRB To Uphold UTU Members Right To Strike>
Story: TORONTO, Feb. 19 /CNW/ - United Steelworkers' (USW) National Director Ken Neumann said Monday that the Canada Industrial Relations Board should dismiss CN Rail's application and confirm that the strike by the United Transportation Union (UTU) is legal.    "The job of the CIRB should be to assist the parties back to the bargaining table," said Neumann. "The UTU is in a legitimate struggle to achieve a fair and decent contract for the men and women who keep the railway running and the economy moving. Fighting the union through the CIRB using a technicality diverts energy away from the main issue - that is, negotiating a settlement to the dispute."    The USW and the UTU signed a strategic alliance last summer, committing both unions to work together more closely and share resources where there is mutual advantage, as well as teaming up on a number of public policy issues. UTU is one of Canada's oldest unions, dating back to 1883, with a long history of negotiating contracts in the transportation sector.    The USW represents more than 280,000 men and women working in every sector of Canada's economy, including about 40,000 workers in the rail, air, marine, taxi and trucking industries.    "Steelworkers support UTU members' right to collective bargaining, including their right to strike for a decent settlement with CN," said Neumann. "We are prepared to help in any way the UTU thinks will help achieve its goals."         /CONTACT: Ken Neumann, (416) 487-1571, (416) 558-2510     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 09:21 ET (14:21 GMT)

Headline: EARNINGS PREVIEW: RWE '06 Net Pft Seen +60% On Special Items
Story: By Jan Hromadko   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     FRANKFURT (Dow Jones)--RWE AG (RWE.XE), Germany's largest power producer in terms of generation capacity, Friday is expected to report a 60% increase in full-year 2006 net profit due mainly to special gains from asset disposals and a tax rebate.   Ten analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswires on average forecast RWE to report a net profit of EUR3.57 billion compared with EUR2.23 billion a year earlier. The Essen-based company itself has projected net profit to increase by more than 40% on the year in 2006.   The improvement mainly comes from a EUR700 million book gain from the sale of U.K. water unit Thames Water Holdings PLC and a EUR600 million gain from a German corporate tax rebate.   Last October, RWE agreed to sell Thames Water to Kemble Water Ltd., a consortium led by Australia's Macquarie Bank Ltd. (MBL.AU), for EUR11.9 billion.   In December, RWE said 2006 net profit will be boosted by a tax rebate as part of a new version of Germany's corporate income tax code.   This will likely result in an increased dividend payout for full-year 2006, given that RWE has pledged to increase its dividend payout ratio to 70% and 80% for 2006 and 2007. The company paid EUR1.75 per share for 2005.   Analysts said high European power and natural gas prices should also have continued to drive earnings and sales in 2006.   However, an outage at RWE's nuclear power plant Biblis, stretching over several months, as well as regulatory intervention into grid fees will likely show a negative impact on earnings, analysts said.   As a result, analysts expect full-year operating profit to grow only 15% to EUR6.19 billion from EUR5.37 billion, but still higher than the 5% to 10% growth forecast by the company itself.   Analysts also said they expect full-year sales to increase around 12% to EUR44.14 billion from EUR39.49 billion.   RWE is Friday expected to give an update on its plan to publicly float its U.S. water unit American Water Works. The company previously said an initial public offering could happen in the second half of 2007.   Investors' focus Friday will also be on RWE's comments on its growth strategy in a consolidating European energy sector and a full-year 2007 outlook.   In the past, RWE said it was focusing on organic growth, while monitoring the market for small- and medium-sized acquisition opportunities to round off its business portfolio.   RWE has ruled out that it would make a headline-grabbing acquisition despite the book gain from the Thames Water sale and the expected proceeds from the American Water IPO.   At 1201 GMT, RWE shares traded down EUR0.35, or 0.4%, at EUR82.10 in a firmer broader market.     Company Web site: http://www.rwe.com     -By Jan Hromadko, Dow Jones Newswires; +49 69 29 725 503; jan.hromadko@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 07:05 ET (12:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Update To Preliminary Economic Assessment On Marathon PGM-Cu Project Indicates 13 1/2 Year Mine Life>MAR.T
Story: TORONTO, Feb. 19 /CNW Telbec/ - Marathon PGM Corporation ("the Company") (TSX: MAR) is pleased to report that an update to the June 2006 Preliminary Economic Assessment ("PEA") has been completed on the Company's Marathon PGM-Cu property by P&E Mining Consultants Inc. of Brampton, Ontario ("P&E"). The complete report will be filed on Sedar and the Company's web site, www.marathonpgm.com, within 45 days of the issue of this press release.    The Company drilled 108 holes for 21,800 meters in 2006 (excluding the holes drilled in the Dunlop Zone). These drilling results were added to the prior drilling on the property for a total of 83,104 meters of drilling. P&E completed an updated in-pit resource in January 2007 that was used as a basis to update the June 2006 PEA.    Project Cash Flow    On an initial capital cost of C$261 million, assuming 100% financing of the project through equity and the use of Jan 31, 2007 18-month trailing average metal prices for Au, Pt and Pd with a US$2.00/lb Cu price, the project has a pre-tax payback of 3.5 years and generates a net pre-tax cash flow of C$512 million over an estimated mine life of 13 1/2 years. This results in a pre tax IRR of 24.0% and an NPV of C$239 million at a discount rate of 7%. The sensitivity of these outcomes to changes in key assumptions is summarized in the table below.          <<      ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 18 month trailing average metal price scenario, the cash  operating cost for palladium (Pd), platinum (Pt) and gold (Au) is US$107/oz  for the first four years of production and US$144/oz for the life of mine  average. Cash operating costs includes all on site costs plus smelter charges,  concentrate freight and refining charges, less copper revenue, which is  treated as a reduction in costs. The cash operating cost does not include  capital costs. During the first 4 years of production the project is estimated  to produce an annual average of 195,000 ounces of payable Pd, Pt and Au and  36.5 million pounds of payable copper (Cu), while over the anticipated life of  mine the project is estimated to produce a total of 2.1 million ounces of  payable Pd, Pt and Au and 425.6 million pounds of payable copper (Cu).      The mine plan calls for mining 6.3 million tonnes of ore per year for  11 years and stockpiling 15.8 million tonnes of low grade material. The low  grade material would then be milled in the last 3 years at a rate of  6.3 millions per year. portion of the resource  estimate based on drilling from 342 drill holes and sampling from 261 surface  channels. An inverse distance squared (1/d2) interpolation method was employed  to develop grade models for Cu, Au, Pt and Pd. The potentially mineable  tonnage was determined by applying a C$7.79/tonne NSR cut-off value to blocks  within an optimized and designed pit. The NSR calculation was derived from  metal prices of US$2.00/lb for Cu, US$569/oz for Au, US$1,085/oz for Pt and  US$293 for Pd at a $C/$US exchange rate of $0.871. Recoveries to concentrate  averaged 84.1% for Cu, 60.0% for Au, 75.5% for Pt and 79.9% for Pd at an  average concentration ratio of 103.3:1. Concentrate shipping was estimated at  C$18/tonne and smelter treatment charges at C$135/tonne. Smelter payables were  95% for Cu, 90% for Au, 90% for Pt and 90% for Pd. Refining charges were  $US0.10/lb for Cu and US$15/oz for Au, Pt and Pd. Pit optimization was carried  out with 55 degree slopes, C$1.17/tonne ore mining cost, C$1.09/tonne waste  mining cost, C$7.30/tonne processing and a $0.49/tonne G & A cost. The increase in vessel expenses was due to the acquisition of new vessels in 2006 and 2005 as well as legal fees and expenses from an unsuccessful claim in arbitration against an insurer of approximately $2,700,000 and $3,800,000 for the three and twelve months ended December 31, 2006, respectively. Average Daily Vessel Expenses are computed using the number of days in the period which OMI owned the vessel.       (1) Consistent with general practice in the tanker shipping  industry, we use TCE revenue (defined as voyage and time charter  revenues less voyage expenses) as a measure of equating revenue  generated from a voyage charter to revenue generated from a time  charter. TCE revenue, a non-GAAP measure, provides additional  meaningful information in conjunction with Revenues, the most directly  comparable GAAP measure because it assists us in making operating  decisions about the deployment of our vessels and their performance.  Voyage expenses comprise all expenses relating to particular voyages,  including bunker fuel expenses, port fees, canal tolls and brokerage  commissions. Under time-charter contracts the charterer pays the  voyage expenses (except brokerage commissions), whereas under voyage  charter contracts the shipowner pays the voyage expenses. TCE Revenue  and Expenses includes revenue and expense generated by the Libra  product carrier pool. As of December 31, 2006, the Libra pool included  1 of OMI's product carriers (beginning in November 2006) and 1 product  carrier (beginning in December 2006) owned by another pool member.       (2) During the three and twelve months ended December 31, 2006,  OMI recognized profit sharing revenue of approximately $1,844,000 and  $19,426,000, respectively, compared to $190,000 and $14,922,000 for  the three and twelve months ended December 31, 2005, respectively.       (3) In 2006, 5 product carriers (4 handymaxes and 2 handysize)  were delivered from the shipyard: 1 in January, 1 in February, 2 in  March and 1 in May. In 2006, 5 product carriers were sold: in March, 2  Panamax vessels were sold and leased back (operating lease) on a  bareboat charter arrangement; in October, 1 vessel was sold; in  November, 1 vessel was sold and leased back (operating lease) on a  time charter arrangement; and in December, 1 vessel was sold and  entered into the Libra pool by the new owner. In 2005, 5 product  carriers (2 handymaxes and 3 handysize) were delivered from the  shipyard: 1 in January, 1 in March, 1 in May, and 2 in July.       (4) During 2006, OMI sold 3 product carriers in sale and leaseback  transactions; 2 were bareboat chartered back in April 2006, with  charters expiring in April and July 2010, and 1 was time chartered  back in November 2006, with its charter expiring in November 2009.       (5) The average daily vessel expense for the three and twelve  months ended December 31, 2006, excludes amounts for legal fees and  expenses from an unsuccessful arbitration claim against an insurer of  approximately $2,700,000 and $3,800,000, respectively, from the  computation of daily expense. Headline: : Dendrite Introduces New Sales Force Effectiveness Solution in Japan
Story: BEDMINSTER, N.J.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--February 19, 2007--   Dendrite International, Inc. (NASDAQ: DRTE) announced today a new Sales Force Effectiveness solution for the Japanese life sciences market. The new solution, Mobile Intelligence(TM) - Japan Edition, has already been rolled out by its first multinational customer.     Mobile Intelligence - Japan Edition will provide Dendrite Japan's existing customers on its market leading j-forceWEB(TM) and j-forceNET(TM) solutions with enhanced functionality on a new technology platform. Built using Dendrite's .NET Technology Framework and with human-centered design enhancements that mirror the way Japanese pharmaceutical sales representatives work in the field, Mobile Intelligence - Japan Edition can improve sales force productivity.     "Dendrite continues to improve our solutions to reflect the needs of local and regional pharmaceutical markets", said Jean-Paul Modde, President, Dendrite Asia Pacific. "Our leadership position in the Japanese market gives us a clear understanding of our customer's future requirements, and we plan to introduce more innovative products to meet their needs."     Dendrite recently announced that over 25,000 pharmaceutical users in Japan are now using its sales effectiveness solutions, a market share exceeding 40 percent. The Mobile Intelligence - Japan Edition is also fully integrated with Dendrite's new j-forceWIRELESS(TM) system, a mobile-phone solution for the Asian market that increases the mobility of sales representatives at life sciences companies.       About Dendrite     Founded in 1986, Dendrite International (NASDAQ: DRTE) enables sales, marketing, clinical and compliance solutions for the global pharmaceutical industry. The company has clients in more than 50 countries and includes the world's top 20 pharmaceutical companies. For more information, please visit www.dendrite.com.     Note: Dendrite is a registered trademark of Dendrite International, Inc.     FORWARD LOOKING INFORMATION: This document contains forward-looking statements that may be identified by such forward-looking terminology as "expect," "believe," "anticipate," "will," "intend," "plan," "target," "outlook," "guidance," and similar statements or variations. All of our "outlook" information constitutes forward looking statements. Such forward-looking statements are based on our current expectations, estimates, assumptions and projections and involve significant risks and uncertainties, including risks associated with estimating and planning for revenues based on customer decisions and unanticipated and unplanned for events over a 12 month or more period; risks which may result from our dependence on the pharmaceutical industry; our fixed expenses in relation to fluctuating revenues and variations in customers' budget cycles; dependence on certain major customers, including the risk associated with our largest customer's plans to transition a significant portion of its U.S. sales force effectiveness services needs; fluctuations in quarterly revenues due to lengthy sales and implementation cycles; our ability to successfully complete our Operational Effectiveness program and to achieve the cost savings in the amounts and time periods expected and budgeted; changes in demand for our products and services attributable to any weakness experienced in the economy or mergers, acquisitions and consolidations in the pharmaceutical industry; risks associated with foreign currency fluctuations as they affect our non-U.S. operations; risks associated with our expanded international operations and our ability to adopt and respond successfully to the unique risks involved in our non-U.S. operations; any difference between estimated and actual stock option expense; and risks associated with reviewing and considering strategic options, as previously announced, and with any transaction occurring or being consummated at any subsequent time. Headline: Depfa Bank Plans Euro Subordinated Hybrid Bond Issue
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Germany's Depfa Bank is planning to sell a step-up hybrid Tier 1 bond issue, one of the lead managers on the deal said Monday.   BNP Paribas and JPMorgan will be lead managers on the euro-denominated issue, which is expected to launch and price in the near future, subject to market conditions and following a European roadshow.   Moody's Investors Service Inc. rates the issuer A2, while Standard & Poor's Corp. rates it A and Fitch Ratings rates it A+.     -By Kate Haywood, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0) 20 7842 9315; kate.haywood@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 06:12 ET (11:12 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: SmartMoney(3/1) Street Smart -- CEO Interview
Story: (From SMARTMONEY)     By Dyan Machan   Kevin Sharer, Amgen     Kevin Sharer, CEO of Amgen, has a militant look that belies his relaxed sweater-and-shirt attire. In fact, it belies the whole laid-back, collegial feel of the biotech company, with its scattered waterfalls and Zen garden inhabiting a 194-acre campus in Thousand Oaks, Calif. But in Sharer's sunlit office is a statue of a fearsome Chinese warrior; we found Sharer in a similar mood. Sitting ramrod straight, the 59-year-old CEO looked every bit the former Navy man he is. The Amgen chief is going head-to-head with both Johnson & Johnson and Roche in the marketplace and the courthouse to defend Amgen's franchises. It's more than just business. When asked if he ever wished to emulate venerated pharmaceutical giant Johnson & Johnson, Sharer snaps: "Never. Never. Never. We are complete foes."   Sharer started his career in the U.S. Navy; by 27, he was a lieutenant commander on a nuclear submarine. Figuring he could rise faster in a corporation than in the military, he jumped ship to McKinsey & Co., then later to General Electric and MCI. Sharer joined Amgen as president and chief operating officer in 1992 and quickly learned the language of biotechnology, which uses genetic engineering to find cures. Eight years later he was named chief executive. "The development of biopharmaceutical drugs is the most difficult managerial job I've ever had," says Sharer. "Nothing is remotely close."   Once at the helm in 2000, Sharer made waves with a startling $11 billion acquisition of Immunex, best known for Enbrel, its blockbuster rheumatoid arthritis drug. He then swept the management decks and injected some regimentation into what had been Amgen's free-spirited startup culture. Today Amgen has grown-up problems: It faces unprecedented competition in its anemia drugs, legislators are threatening to reduce Medicare reimbursement, and Wall Street keeps demanding more and more blockbusters to maintain double-digit growth. Because all of this makes running a nuclear submarine look easy, SmartMoney senior writer Dyan Machan sat down with the Amgen chief to solicit his thoughts.     SM: Your anemia drugs Epogen and Aranesp, which make up half of Amgen's  $12.4 billion in sales, are under some serious competitive attack.   KS: It's our biggest single market, but we have three other multibillion-dollar products.     SM: Okay, but in the meantime, Roche is expected to introduce its anemia drug Cera this year.   KS: We are suing for patent infringement to stop them. Roche introduced its product in Europe because Epogen was going off patent in Europe. Since they had it already, they decided to take a free shot at the U.S. market [where Amgen's Epogen patent remains]. My opinion is that they offer no innovation.     SM: Some very smart people are betting you're going to lose.   KS: It sounds like the same people who said we would lose the patent case in 2003. We did not. [In 2003 a federal appeals court ruled that Transkaryotic Therapies' Dynepo drug infringed on two Amgen patents.]     SM: You have a Hatfield-McCoy history with J&J. Can't you two just get along?   KS: Everyone needs a tough competitor to be good. So I respect that. However, we're going to fight J&J everywhere for a long time. We've been doing that for 15 years, and it will never stop.     SM: Johnson & Johnson is suing Amgen for antitrust violations; it claims your practice of bundling the competition-free Neulasta [a drug that bolsters white blood cell production and is used by chemotherapy patients] with anemia drug Aranesp [which competes with J&J's drug Procrit] hinders competition.   KS: Physicians can buy our drugs individually. But if they want the very best price, they have to combine it. It is not an unusual tactic. Giving discounts for bigger combinations was pioneered by J&J.     SM: What's in your pipeline?   KS: Vectibix, for colorectal cancer, is just out. It has multibillion-dollar potential. The reception has been great. Also coming is Denosumab for osteoporosis and for cancer; key data will be available in 2008.     SM: Denosumab won't come to market until the next decade. How does that help now?   KS: Stocks tend to move on clinical data. If revenue doesn't show up, that's another issue. The year 2008 is going to be an important one. We should have a ruling on the Roche patent case, and we will have data on Denosumab.     SM: Why not have your scientists make a wrinkle cream for a big payout?   KS: We find cures only for grievous illnesses. We won't make a drug for a toenail infection. Drug development is hard; you can't do everything. These illnesses present large, unmet needs. We aren't completely altruistic. But we do ask ourselves: What did you do that counts? It helps us attract good people.     SM: You have raised your research and development budget every year. This year you promise another double-digit advance. That sounds desperate.   KS: It's the opposite. There are so many promising areas where we want to invest -- Alzheimer's, Diabetes, Parkinson's.     SM: Your biggest customer is Uncle Sam. The new Congress makes no secret that it wants to negotiate lower prices for Medicare patients.   KS: There is a societal need to better manage health care costs.     SM: Diplomatic answer. Now set Congress straight!   KS: The new leadership of Congress may be surprised at how effective the private plans have been in negotiating prices. I think they'll find government negotiations won't be the financial bonanza they imagine.     SM: Speaking of anemia, your stock sells at half the multiple of Genentech. Why?   KS: When I started, Amgen had a 70 price-to-earnings ratio, largely because Aranesp was new. Genentech has a big product right now -- Avastin [for lung and colorectal cancer]. We have some uncertainty.     SM: You're sounding unsure about the case against Roche.   KS: We are going to win. If we beat Roche and Denosumab is a success, Amgen is a very good value, and now is the time to buy. If you think something else, you buy someone else. I think as CEO if you're not betting your job, the company is not going to move ahead.     SM: Are you willing to bet your job right here and now?   KS: If Denosumab fails, if we can't defend against Roche and if J&J beats us -- I won't be in such good shape.     SM: Is running Amgen more difficult than running a nuclear submarine?   KS: I was the No. 3 officer and 27 years old. I was overmatched then. I've had a lot of time to prepare for this job.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 06:00 ET (11:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ: XM Satellite, Sirius In Final Merger Talks
Story: By Dennis K. Berman and Sarah McBride     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Satellite radio operators XM Satellite Radio Holdings (XMSR) and Sirius Satellite Radio Inc. (SIRI) are in final merger discussions, a person familiar with the matter said Monday. The two are nearing an agreement but have yet to ratify a definitive contract, this person said.   If completed, a deal would create a single satellite-based giant, a fact that could prove a difficult issue for antitrust and communications regulators. Already Federal Communications Commission Chairman Kevin Martin has signaled some resistance to a coupling of the two services, which feature rival menus of sports, music and talk-radio programming.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   But the two sides are likely to argue that the proliferation of Internet-based radio, digital music players, and new Hybrid Digital-radio formats creates a vigorous competitive market for such media. Indeed, in surveys, consumers rarely can differentiate between the two companies, which have spent hundreds of millions trying to appeal to them. As of Friday, Sirius carried a market capitalization of $5.2 billion. Sirius was valued at about $3.8 billion. Word of the talks was first reported by The New York Post.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 13:43 ET (18:43 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE:Japan Watchdog Recommends Punishment For Nomura Staff
Story: (Updates with Nomura Securities' comment, details on investment product.)       By Kazuhiro Shimamura     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     TOKYO (Dow Jones)--Japan's Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission recommended Monday that the Financial Services Agency order Nomura Securities Co. to take appropriate steps after an employee sold some investment products without providing sufficient explanation.   According to the agency, an official at the firm's Kyoto branch in western Japan gave misleading information to 10 customers about the risks of structured bonds.   The official sold the structured bonds between October 2005 and April 2006 without clearly explaining the possibility of the investment product's value falling below its principals, the financial watchdog said in a statement.   Nomura Securities, a core subsidiary of Nomura Holdings Inc. (8604.TO), said in a statement it "takes the recommendation seriously and will ensure thorough legal compliance to prevent a reoccurrence."       -By Kazuhiro Shimamura, Dow Jones Newswires; 813-5255-2929; kazuhiro.shimamura@dowjones.com   -Edited by Mayuko Ota     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 04:58 ET (09:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: EARNINGS PREVIEW:Anglo American Capital Return, Revamp Eyed
Story: By Jackie Range   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     LONDON (Dow Jones)--Anglo American PLC's (AAUK) earnings Wednesday look set to be a sideshow to capital return and the diversified resources and mining company's restructuring plans.   The diamonds, platinum and gold giant, which reports full-year earnings at 0700 GMT Wednesday, is expected to this year, or over the next 12 months, return capital worth some $4 billion to more than $5 billion, according to analysts who follow the company and a press report.   Anglo American Aug. 4 unveiled a $4 billion buyback program. Since then, the company has bought back some $3 billion of shares, a company spokeswoman said. An announcement Wednesday that it would add to that amount would "send a strong message of management's confidence on the outlook for 2007," said Credit Suisse in a note.   Mining companies have been generating large profits from strong demand for commodities, as Asian economies industrialize. Large-scale capital return programs like that predicted from Anglo American have become a common feature of mining company earnings updates, as commodity producers strive to keep their balance sheets lean.   BHP Billiton PLC (BHP), the world's biggest mining company by market capitalization, unveiled a $10 million share buyback with its half-year results Feb. 7.   Analysts are also watching for progress on the company's demerger of Mondi, its paper and packaging division, and its disposal of its 41.8% stake in world No. 3 gold producer AngloGold Ashanti Ltd. (AU).   Anglo American is seeking a higher valuation for its business by becoming more focused on its core mining assets. The company's paper and packaging division is a lower-margin business than its key base metals and platinum assets, and Anglo believes a separate listing for Mondi will mean investors rate both companies' stock more highly.   Anglo has said it will move on with plans for Mondi's London and Johannesburg IPO in the second quarter of this year. Talks on the IPO plans are under way with the U.K. and South African regulators, an Anglo spokeswoman said.   The market also will be watching Wednesday for an update on Anglo's plans to exit AngloGold Ashanti. So far the company has said it plans to sell out in the next two to three years.   A press report Sunday said Russian gold giant OAO Polyus Gold (PLZL.RS), a gold company spun out of Russia's biggest mining company by market capitalization OAO Norilsk Nickel (GMKN.RS), had approached Anglo American to buy the stake in the gold miner. Polyus doesn't currently have any AngloGold Ashanti shares.   But a person familiar with Polyus' thinking told Dow Jones Newswires that such a move didn't appear to be a logical step for Polyus.   According to three analysts surveyed by Dow Jones Newswires, Anglo American is expected to report earnings before interest and tax of $9.826 billion for the 12 months to Dec. 31, 2006, up from $6.376 billion the previous year.    The company's base metals division - which produces metals including copper, nickel and zinc - is expected to be its strongest performer. Anglo's gold, diamond, platinum and iron ore subsidiaries have already made their earnings public.   At 1431 GMT Monday, Anglo American's shares were trading up 2.7%, or 69 pence, at 2607 pence, outperforming a mildly positive mining sector. One analyst said the company's shares had gained on investor hopes for increased capital return Wednesday.   The market also will be interested to get any insight into incoming Chief Executive Officer Cynthia Carroll's plans for Anglo American. The former Alcan Inc. (AL) executive formally becomes CEO on March 1, but officially joined the company Jan. 15.   Sector watchers said former aluminum executive Carroll will be looking to improve the company's operational performance and make progress on the restructuring, but also to put the company on a stronger footing at a time when it's often named as a takeover target.   Amid rapid consolidation in mining and metals industries, broker Numis Securities describes Anglo American as a "large but tempting target." Diversified mining company Xstrata PLC (XTA.LN) is frequently named by sector watchers as a potential buyer. Xstrata declined to comment.   Numis said a deal to buy Anglo American "could be financed through the sale of assets with minimal reorganization required." The fact that some of the company's subsidiaries are listed makes them easier to value, and a deal easier to do, the broker added.   A spokeswoman for Anglo American declined to comment on the potential for any additional capital return, selling AngloGold Ashanti shares to Polyus and the company as a takeover target.     Company Web site: http://www.angloamerican.co.uk     -By Jackie Range, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 207 842 9257; jackie.range@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 09:48 ET (14:48 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Cardinal Health Names Michael C. Kaufmann to Lead Medical Segment of Healthcare Supply Chain Services
Story: Linda S. Harty succeeds Kaufmann as CFO of Healthcare Supply Chain Services; Jorge M. Gomez named Treasurer       DUBLIN, Ohio, Feb. 19 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Cardinal Health, the leading provider of products and services supporting the health-care industry, announced today the appointment of Michael C. Kaufmann as group president of its $7-billion Healthcare Supply Chain Services Medical Segment.     Kaufmann, 45, will be responsible for Cardinal Health's business that distributes medical, surgical and laboratory products from nearly 3,000 manufacturers to hospitals and other care providers in the United States and Canada.  The segment is also a leading manufacturer and distributor of surgical kits used by hospitals and surgery centers worldwide.     Kaufmann will report to Mark W. Parrish, chief executive officer of the company's Healthcare Supply Chain Services sector.  Kaufmann replaces Thomas M. Slagle, who is leaving Cardinal Health to pursue other interests.     "At each point in Mike's career with Cardinal Health, he has demonstrated a strong commitment to our customers, while developing the employees on his team and maintaining a disciplined focus on financial results," Parrish said. "Mike's depth of health-care experience and his proven leadership skills will serve us well as we grow this important part of Cardinal Health's business."     Kaufmann was most recently the chief financial officer (CFO) of Healthcare Supply Chain Services.  He joined the company 16 years ago and has held positions of increasing responsibility in general management and finance, including leading Cardinal Health's pharmaceutical repackaging business, sales and marketing for retail pharmaceutical distribution, and pharmaceutical procurement.  He was instrumental in leading the company's transition to a fee-based model within its pharmaceutical distribution business, leading to improvements in the financial performance of Cardinal Health's largest segment.     Kaufmann graduated from Ohio Northern University with a degree in accounting and management.  He became a certified public accountant early in his career while employed by Arthur Andersen.  His appointment is effective immediately.     Linda S. Harty, 46, replaces Kaufmann as executive vice president, Finance and chief financial officer of Healthcare Supply Chain Services.  She has served as treasurer of Cardinal Health since joining the company in January 2005.  Jorge M. Gomez, 39, formerly vice president and assistant treasurer succeeds Harty as the company's senior vice president and treasurer.        About Cardinal Health     Headquartered in Dublin, Ohio, Cardinal Health, Inc. (NYSE: CAH) is an $81 billion, global company serving the health-care industry with a broad portfolio of products and services.  Through its diverse offerings, Cardinal Health delivers health-care solutions that help customers reduce their costs, improve safety and productivity, and deliver better care to patients.  The company manufactures, packages and distributes pharmaceuticals and medical supplies, offers a range of clinical services and develops automation products that improve the management and delivery of supplies and medication for hospitals, physician offices and pharmacies.  Ranked No. 19 on the Fortune 500, Cardinal Health employs more than 55,000 people on six continents.  More information about the company may be found at www.cardinalhealth.com.    SOURCE  Cardinal Health, Inc.       /CONTACT: Media, Jim Mazzola, +1-614-757-3690, jim.mazzola@cardinal.com, or Investors, Jason Strohm, +1-614-757-7542, jason.strohm@cardinal.com      /Web site: http://www.cardinalhealth.com/     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 09:00 ET (14:00 GMT)

Headline: SmartMoney(3/1) Stockscreen: A New "Dogs Of The Dow" Theory
Story: (From SMARTMONEY)     By Jack Hough   Splitting profits among shareholders was easy until the 17th century. Merchant shippers, among the earliest share companies, would simply fold after each voyage. The value of the goods the ship returned with -- hopefully more than it set out with -- was divided among investors.   The rise of permanent stock-issuing companies like Dutch East India in 1602 was made possible by periodic profit distributions, otherwise known as dividends. Dutch East paid dividends sporadically through 1635 but yearly thereafter; payments sometimes topped 60 percent. The larger dividends sparked strong demand for shares. They multiplied sixfold in value by 1650.   For most of the time since then, that relationship has held. Big dividends have tended to drive share prices higher.   This column, were it written 80 years ago, would be an easy affair. We'd simply look each month for strong companies with low share prices relative to their dividend payments (otherwise known as high dividend yields) and call them bargains.   The "Dogs of the Dow" strategy, popularized by Michael O'Higgins in his 1991 book Beating the Dow, uses just such a strategy. It chooses the 10 highest-yielding of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow Jones Industrial Average at the start of each year. Money poured into investment trusts based on the strategy in the mid-1990s. The sales pitch wasn't difficult; the Dogs had beaten the Dow by about three percentage points a year over the 50 years ended 1995.   Then the strategy stopped working. Though they handily beat the Dow last year, the Dogs have disappointed since 1996. They've averaged annual gains of 6.7 percent and dividends of 3.4 percent, versus 9.4 percent and 2.1 percent for the index. Those 11 years could be just a fluke, but there's evidence to suggest the Dogs strategy needs a makeover. The good news is that an updated version I'll explain in a moment might help you collect big dividends and beat the broad market's total return by five percentage points a year. For young investors, that's easily enough to buy a decade of early-retirement time.   Dividends began losing their predictive power in the early 1980s with the rise of stock "repurchases." By repurchasing their shares, companies can reduce their share counts. That makes remaining shares more valuable, since a lower share count results in greater earnings per share. Both dividends and repurchases represent companies' returning profits to shareholders, but the latter are more tax-efficient. Dividends have been taxed as investor income since the launch of the U.S. income tax in the early 20th century-unfairly, some argue, since the payments have already been taxed once as corporate profits. Funds spent on buybacks aren't taxed as investor income.   You'd think share repurchases would have long ago eclipsed dividend payments because of the tax efficiency, but companies showed little interest in buying their own shares before the 1980s. Perhaps that's partly because they feared being viewed as share-price manipulators. Unscrupulous companies had in the past used big stock purchases to pump up their share prices and get other investors buying, only to start issuing heaps of new shares at the higher prices. In 1982 the Securities and Exchange Commission created rule 10b-18 in order to prevent such activity. It placed restrictions on the volume and timing of buybacks. In doing so, it guaranteed companies that follow the new rules freedom from suspicion (so long as they don't base buys on inside information). As a result, the volume of repurchases exploded. Today they make up about half of all shareholder payouts (dividends plus repurchases), up from around 10 percent before the SEC rule. This surge has raised new questions about the usefulness of the dividend yield alone. Wouldn't a new yield that represents dividends and repurchases better represent how much cash companies lavish on shareholders? And if dividends have historically been a good predictor of share-price gains, wouldn't this new yield be a better one?   A new study scheduled for publication in the Journal of Finance in April offers answers. Four finance professors -- Jacob Boudoukh, Roni Michaely, Matthew Richardson and Michael Roberts at Arison (Israel), Cornell, New York University and Wharton, respectively -- studied dividends, share repurchases and stock returns for thousands of companies over the 32 years ended 2003. The period was a particularly good one for stocks; their entire sample averaged annual returns of just over 13 percent. The four studied stocks with high dividend yields and found that they outperformed the entire sample by a couple of percentage points a year -- interesting but, statistically speaking, hardly a reason to get your broker on the phone. Then they ranked stocks by what they call net payout yield. It consists of the money spent on dividends and share repurchases, minus funds raised through new-share issuance. Stocks with the highest net payout yields, the researchers found, outperformed their sample by five percentage points a year. Over their  study period that would have been the difference between turning $10,000 into a half million dollars and turning it into more than $2 million.   The implication for growth-and-income-style investors is clear. Don't focus solely on companies that pay big dividends. Rather, look for those that spend freely on shareholders, regardless of whether they use dividends or repurchases to do so. The study compared the original Dogs of the Dow strategy with an updated one based on dividends and share repurchases between July 1983 and December 2003. The original Dogs returned an average of 16.2 percent a year, easily beating the Dow's 13.4 percent return. But the new-and-improved Dogs returned 19.1 percent a year.   Tracking down repurchase spending is cumbersome but not that difficult. Companies report the dollar amounts they spend on dividends and stock repurchases each quarter on their cash-flow statements. SmartMoney.com, for one, lists the information on its stock-quote pages. (Click the "financials" tab.) Calculating your own net payout yield is straightforward: Add the past four quarters' worth of dollars spent on dividends to dollars spent on repurchases over the same period, and divide the result by the company's market value. If you use a different source for cash-flow statements, just keep in mind that the numbers are often reported cumulatively. So what looks like dollars spent in the third quarter might be dollars spent in the first three quarters combined. If the numbers are snowballing from quarter to quarter by fairly regular amounts, it's a cumulative statement.   Searching for stocks with high net payout yields requires a powerful stock screener. I used the one at Reuters Research to compile the list below. Starting with the 30 Dow Industrial stocks, I calculated their net payout yields as described above and selected the top 10. That's it.   The companies are all familiar names. All but two of the 10 -- Exxon and Disney -- have underperformed the Dow over the past year. That's to be expected. Payout yields become larger, after all, as share prices drop. Both the original Dogs strategy and this one are, in effect, attempts to methodically pick stocks that are out of favor in order to score bargains. The average stock on the list produced a gain of 7.9 percent over the past year, underperforming the DJIA by 5.2 percentage points. But the companies aren't struggling to make money, and their shares might be cheap. On average, the companies produced a profit return of nearly 18 percent on the capital they used over the past year, versus  11 percent for all 30 companies in the index. Their shares trade at an average of 16 times forecast earnings for this fiscal year. The index's price/earnings ratio is 17.   ---   JACK HOUGH can be reached by e-mail at jhough@smartmoney.com.   ---   SmartMoney.com: To run your own stock screens, go to  www.smartmoney.com/stockscreener.   ---                       THE NEW DOGS OF THE DOW      By focusing on both dividends and share repurchases, investors can find  stocks likely to outperform. Headline: : ComEd Offers Energy Saving Information for Renters and Customers with Electric Space Heat During Frigid Winter Season
Story: CHICAGO, Feb. 19 /PRNewswire/ -- As Northern Illinois' frigid winter weather continues, ComEd has added to its CARE (Customers' Affordable Reliable Energy) Web site more energy-savings tips for electric space heat customers, whose electric usage dramatically increases during periods of extreme cold. ComEd also has added new energy-efficiency tips for renters.     "Everyone can take steps to reduce their energy use and lower their bills, no matter what type of home you have," said Anne Pramaggiore, senior vice president, ComEd regulatory and external affairs. "By providing customized energy-saving information and tips for electric space heaters and renters, we hope even more ComEd customers will embrace energy efficiency to save money and help protect our environment."     About 190,000 customers, or 6 percent of ComEd's residential customer base, use electricity as their primary source of heating for their home, rather than heating with natural gas. These electric space heat customers face a slightly higher annual average electric bill increase of roughly 28 percent over their past bills. During the winter months, these customers will see higher increases because the steep rate reduction they previously received for heating their homes with electricity is gradually being reduced. In the summer, these customers will experience a significantly lower increase.     Customers with electric space heat can particularly benefit from reducing their energy use during the winter heating season. ComEd offers the following money-savings tips for residential electric space heat customers.           -- Keep your thermostat between 68 and 70 degrees -- every degree you can          lower your temperature setting will save you an average of 3 percent          on your heating bill.       -- Lower your thermostat at night and during unoccupied hours.       -- Clean vents and registers to optimize air flow.       -- Use your ceiling fan to move warm air from the ceiling into the living          space.       -- Open your drapes during sunlight hours and close them at night.       -- If you have a fireplace, close your fireplace dampers and doors.       -- Close vents to rooms that are not in use.         There also are plenty of way renters can reduce their energy bills too. Following are some changes that renters can make to lower their bills.           -- Turn off unnecessary lights, unplug electronics when not in use, and          adjust your thermostat (higher in summer, lower in winter) before          leaving for work.       -- Keep your refrigerator setting at 40 degrees and your freezer at zero          degrees. Lower temperatures will not improve food preservation and          will only cause higher usage. Also clean your refrigerator coils          (located in the back) regularly to help it operate efficiently.       -- Wait until your dishwasher is full before you run it.       -- When buying consumer electronics and appliances, look for the ENERGY          STAR(R) label. Only items rated in the top of their class for energy          efficiency are awarded this rating.       -- Purchase ENERGY STAR(R)-labeled compact fluorescent light (CFL) bulbs.          Not only do they use 66 percent less energy than standard incandescent          bulbs, they can also last 10 times as long. (And you can take them          with you when you move.)       -- A good time for a renter to pay attention to energy efficiency is          before moving into an apartment.             -- Ask the landlord about the efficiency and maintenance of the              furnace, air conditioner, water heater and appliances.           -- Before you move in, request caulking around the windows and outlet              covers and installation of weather stripping around doors and              windows.           -- Ask to see previous months' energy bills. Try to choose an              apartment with low energy bills.           -- Be sure to point out to the landlord that improving energy              efficiency can help increase the property's value.         The http://www.ComEdCARE.com site, currently equipped with a variety of low- and no-cost tips and tools to help customers manage their energy usage, includes sections especially for electric space heat customers and renters. In fact, the ComEd Energy Doctor has responded to a number of questions from electric space heat customers, which are posted on the site.     ComEd CARE offers a number of energy-efficiency and low-income programs that can help customers reduce their bills as well as the residential rate stabilization plan, which allows residential customers the choice to pay for the rate increase over time. To access the new tips and more information on managing energy bills, customers can log on to http://www.ComEdCARE.com or call 888-806-CARE (2273).     Commonwealth Edison Company (ComEd) is a unit of Chicago-based Exelon Corporation (NYSE: EXC), one of the nation's largest electric utilities with approximately 5.2 million customers and more than $15 billion in annual revenues. ComEd provides service to approximately 3.7 million customers across Northern Illinois, or 70 percent of the state's population.    SOURCE  ComEd       /CONTACT: Judy Rader, ComEd Media Relations, +1-312-394-3500      /Web site: http://www.ComEdCARE.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 10:00 ET (15:00 GMT)

Headline: Australia's Foster's 1H Net A$553.5M; Pre-Items Net A$363M-2-
Story: Foster's also announced a A$400 million off-market buyback. The company said it will cancel the remaining A$1.3 million balance of a A$200 million buyback announced last August.   The drinks group said factoring in the cash requirements of the proposed buyback, it remains confident it will reduce net debt to less than A$3 billion by June 2008.   The result included a A$190 million gain from asset sales, including the sale of the Foster's brand in Europe and its Asian brewing assets.   Total earnings in the Australia, Asia and Pacific region rose 2.5% to A$442.2 million. Foster's has elected to report earnings along regional lines rather than separate its beer and wine businesses.   Foster's said beer, which includes Australia's top selling brand Victoria Bitter, continued to perform well in the region, but its wine business was "disappointing".   Foster's blamed part of the disappointing performance on its new multi-beverage sales distribution system, where sales staff sell across the company's portfolio of beer, wine and spirits to customers.   The company said it remains committed to the model but will increase the focus on wine sales.   Foster's said consumer and customer response to the relaunch of its Rosemount brand, which suffered a sales slump last year, has been strong.   To achieve its targeted return on capital from its global wine business in fiscal 2008, Foster's said it plans to eliminate inefficiencies in wine packaging and Australian export logistics; and improve its multi-beverage sales model.   Group sales for the half year rose 3.5% to A$2.4 billion from A$2.3 billion a year ago.   Foster's declared an interim dividend of 10.75 cents a share up from 9.75 cents a year ago.     -By Susan Murdoch, Dow Jones Newswires; 61-3-9671-4393; susan.murdoch@dowjones.com   -Edited by Paul Dekkers     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 17:27 ET (22:27 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: 2nd UPDATE:Hydro 4Q Net Pft -68.4% On Asset Write-Downs
Story: (This updates an item published at 0738 GMT with additional detail and comments from analysts.)     By Elizabeth Cowley   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     OSLO (Dow Jones)--Norsk Hydro (NHY) Monday reported a 68.4% fall in net profit for the fourth quarter of 2006, reflecting asset write-downs and other special items.   The Norwegian oil and aluminum company said fourth-quarter net profit fell 68.4% to NOK1.32 billion ($216.02 million) from NOK4.19 billion a year earlier.   Operating income fell to NOK4.57 billion versus NOK10.36 billion in the fourth quarter of 2005, significantly below analysts' expectations of a NOK8.0 billion operating profit.   Hydro pinned the weak fourth-quarter figures on its previously announced write-down of $836 million relating to the Front Runner field and nine shelf fields in the Gulf of Mexico.   In addition, impairment charges and costs relating to divestments, closures and plant rationalizations in its aluminum products operations, and unrealized losses on derivative contracts were to blame.   Revenue for the quarter was slightly up at NOK45.72 billion compared with NOK44.51 billion the previous year, on higher year-on-year oil, gas and aluminum prices for the quarter.   Earnings per share from continuing operations decreased to NOK1.00 from NOK3.30.   The company proposed a dividend of NOK5.00 a share for 2006.   Hydro's President and Chief Executive Eivind Reiten said, "Market outlooks for most of Hydro's core products are promising."   "The ongoing restructuring of the aluminum business is well under way, providing a sound basis for Hydro going forward as a focused aluminum and power company with firm growth ambitions," Reiten added.   Analysts' focus was firmly on the company's aluminum division following the announcement in December that Statoil (STO) will take over Hydro's oil and gas assets, under a $30 billion deal due to complete in the third quarter of this year. Reiten said the takeover "is on track."   Analyst Morten Normann of Kaupthing said Hydro's overall aluminum division clean operating profit was slightly higher than Kaupthing's estimate.   He added that the aluminum metals subdivision's performance was more disappointing, with a loss on a London Metals Exchange contract. Even taking that loss into account, there was a negative deviation from forecasts "that was not explained by specific one-off items," Normann said.   Ongoing restructuring within Hydro's aluminum business resulted in a shift to operating profit for Hydro's total aluminum activities of NOK413 million in the fourth quarter versus a loss of NOK1.099 billion in the same period of 2005. Despite this, Hydro said operating income was "heavily influenced by write-downs, costs and charges relating to the restructuring of its downstream aluminum operations."   In its outlook on aluminum markets, the company said that key economic indicators signal "somewhat slower growth" in European, U.S. and Asian aluminum markets in 2007.   It forecast a 7% increase in global primary aluminum consumption in 2007, driven largely by Chinese demand, with European consumption growth expected only 2.5% higher on the year, and U.S. consumption seen 1% lower.   Hydro's first-quarter 2007 aluminum products operations are expected to be positively influenced by progress in its plant rationalization programs, the company said.   Meanwhile, Hydro's oil and energy division saw realized oil prices increase 4% in the fourth quarter versus the same period in 2005, while gas prices rose 6%. In the year as a whole, realized oil prices rose 18% compared with 2005 and realized gas prices lifted 27%.   In the fourth quarter, Hydro produced an average of 595,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, 6,000 boe/d more than a year ago. For the full year, average oil and gas production increased to 573,000 boe/d from 563,000 boe/d in 2005, exceeding its revised target of 570,000 boe/d.   Despite the year-on-year rise, Hydro said production was negatively impacted by production interruptions on partner-operated fields on the Norwegian continental shelf together with lower-than-expected output from its international portfolio.   Hydro retained its 2007 production target of 605,000 boe/d, which represents a 6% increase on realized production in 2006.   At 1005, GMT Hydro shares traded down NOK0.75, or 0.4%, at NOK195.      Company Web site: http://www.hydro.com     -By Elizabeth Cowley, Dow Jones Newswires; +47 22 20 10 58; elizabeth.cowley@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 05:13 ET (10:13 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: FOCUS: HSBC Brand, Distribution Add Weight To Insurance Push
Story: By Henry E. Teitelbaum   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     LONDON (Dow Jones)--As HSBC Holdings PLC (HBC) expands its retail insurance business, it is likely to reveal  something about the value of a global brand.   The banking giant already has one of the world's largest branch networks and commands the kind of balance sheet required to ride out the often long insurance cycles. But HSBC also has a sometimes overlooked asset in its red "hexagon" label, which analysts say it will leverage in markets around the globe as it pursues its goal of doubling profit from insurance over the next five years.   "HSBC is by far the strongest bank in terms of building a global brand," says Jasmine Montgomery, deputy managing director of FutureBrand, a branding consultancy.   She says that HSBC, unlike most financial institutions, can deploy the value of its brand name to virtually "guarantee demand" at the more than 9,500 offices in 81 countries where it has a presence. And because its brand is so instantly recognizable around the world, she says that for HSBC, "the cost of entry in new products is much lower."   By most measures, HSBC has room to grow in insurance; its relative under-representation in the insurance market stands as a significant missed opportunity.   In 2005, HSBC's retail life and non-life insurance business contributed about $2.6 billion, or just over 10%, to group pretax profit of $21 billion, with half coming from the manufacture of life and non-life products and half from distribution.   By comparison, Royal Bank of Scotland PLC (RBS.LN), its nearest U.K. competitor in terms of size and global reach, gets nearly 13% of its annual profit from insurance, while Lloyds TSB Group PLC (LYG) gets more than 26% of its profit from insurance and investments.   Patrick McGuinness, a spokesman for HSBC, concedes that insurance is a sector in which the bank punches below its weight. He says that with 125 million clients worldwide, "we should be able to better penetrate our own customer base" to target demographic shifts and long-term savings trends.   HSBC signaled its growth intentions last year by elevating Clive Bannister to the post of Group Managing Director, Insurance. Bannister, formerly chief executive of Group Private Banking, is credited with HSBC's highly successful expansion in private banking since the late 1999s. His success at HSBC Private Bank came from anticipating trends and making well-timed acquisitions that added services.   "They buy pretty distressed assets at bargain basement prices," said Collins Stewart analyst Alex Potter. Among the key acquisitions Bannister made at HSBC Private Bank was the tax advisory service of Arthur Andersen at auction for $15 million after the parent collapsed in the Enron scandal.   But private banking and insurance are quite different activities, says Potter, who warns that building an insurance business with a policy manufacturing capability "takes time and money," and time is in short supply for some senior management as shareholders fume over HSBC's poor share performance over the past year.   Potter points to HSBC's past "retrenchment" in investment banking as an example of its unwillingness to commit to businesses that don't produce profit quickly.   HSBC shares were virtually flat in 2006 and have since slipped by nearly 2%, in part due to a profit warning that followed news of a sharp rise in provisions to cover loans made in the souring U.S. subprime mortgage market.   Around 1542 GMT Monday, HSBC shares were down 2 pence, or 0.2%, at 912 pence in a higher U.K. shares market.   The market for insurance and investment products in the U.K., the world's third largest, has seen healthy growth in recent years due to changes in investment and retirement planning. According to the Association of British Insurers, annual premium equivalents grew nearly 20% from 2004 to 2005. A similar trend has been underway through much of western Europe, while globally, growth in insurance has accelerated due to demographic changes and wealth creation in emerging economies.   Chris Wheeler, analyst at Bear Stearns, says HSBC could start to address its past failings and show quick results by leveraging its name and branch network.   "They could link up with some of the biggest insurance players in the world", he says, adding that any one of these would be thrilled to have HSBC put its brand on their product as "they have a fantastic distribution network."   Selling other insurers' products under HSBC's brand  meshes well with HSBC's strategy for launching financial "megastores" where it can offer the widest possible range of banking, insurance and investment products.   Ije Nwokorie, senior consultant at branding consultancy Wolff Olins in London, sees opportunity here because many banks are "searching for the purpose and meaning of a branch" in an increasingly commoditized banking industry.   He sees concepts like the megastore as a way for HSBC to differentiate its brand through a customer experience that can "truly integrate with our lives."   HSBC has plans to launch a megastore in London this year and is considering the concept for other major U.K. cities.   Bruno Paulson, analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. says insurance is a "natural thing to sell" at a bank, with  considerable overlap between banking and insurance services.    But he says that in the cross-selling of insurance and investment services, U.K. banks are "still vastly behind the rest of Europe."   A strategy relying on other insurance providers' products carries fewer risks, notes Bear Stearns' Wheeler, who warns that in the insurance business it's not always apparent how to value what you're buying.   That's what Lloyds TSB discovered in 2000 after it paid GBP7 billion to acquire insurance, pensions and asset management group Scottish Widows at what turned out to be the top of the market.   The bank struggled for years with that acquisition before the market recovered. Lloyds TSB is now seeing healthy growth at Scottish Widows, which increased its contribution to parent company results by 15% in 2005 and is expected to grow this even faster in 2006. A spokeswoman for Lloyds TSB, Mary Walsh, said "because we have Scottish Widows we are able to design and manufacture products tailored to the needs and appetite of retail customers and market these through the branch network."   Whether HSBC needs this same manufacturing ability on a global scale is open to question. Bernstein's Paulson says this capability may be useful to own, but is more likely to be justified in "underpenetrated" markets for insurance and investment products.   Even then, he says a bank must consider whether its banking market share is big enough to make the investment worth its while. In Europe, for example, Paulson says it often doesn't pay for a bank to manufacture its own insurance because customers are more interested in seeing a wide choice of options.   "You have to look at it on a market-by-market basis," he says.   Company Web site: http://www.hsbc.com   -By Henry Teitelbaum, Dow Jones Newswires; 44(0)20 7842 9486; henry.teitelbaum@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 11:13 ET (16:13 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Lower Saxony Welcomes Airbus Statement Delay
Story: FRANKFURT (Dow Jones)--The governor of German Federal State Lower Saxony, Christian Wulff, said he welcomes news that airplane maker Airbus has postponed an announcement on its Power8 restructuring program, planned for Tuesday.   "This is a sign that accuracy is more important than speed," Wulff said.   The German economics ministry declined to comment on the interrupted consultation on Power 8.   Airbus has several production sites in Lower Saxony. The Northwestern Federal State is also part of the consortium that is to buy a 7.5% stake in Airbus' parent company European Aeronautic Defence & Space Co. (5730.FR), or EADS, from DaimlerChrysler AG (DCX).   Earlier Monday, EADS said it's postponing the planned announcement on the Power8 restructuring program at its Airbus unit, citing industrial issues over the planned A350 XWB airplane.   The Power8 program is designed to improve Airbus' internal efficiency and competitiveness against Boeing amid a weaker U.S. dollar. Airplanes are sold in dollars and most of EADS' costs are in euros.     Company Web site: http://www.airbus.com                     http://www.eads.com     -By Frankfurt Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +49 69 29 725 500.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 10:46 ET (15:46 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Satellite Radio Rivals XM, Sirius Agree To Merge
Story: NEW YORK (AP)--XM Satellite Radio Holdings Inc. (XMSR) and Sirius Satellite Radio Inc. (SIRI) have agreed to merge, the two companies said Monday.   The deal would consolidate the only two companies in the emerging business of subscription-only satellite radio, and is sure to face tough scrutiny from federal regulators. Investors and analysts have been speculating about a deal for months.   The two companies said in a statement that Mel Karmazin, the CEO of Sirius, would become chief executive of the new company while Gary Parsons, the chairman of XM, would remain in that role. XM's CEO Hugh Panero will remain to oversee closing the of the deal, they said.   The deal would face significant regulatory hurdles in Washington, including a Federal Communications Commission rule that clearly states that one satellite radio provider cannot buy the other one. However, that rule could be waived.   A combination would also have to meet antitrust approval from the Department of Justice. The companies are expected to argue that they compete not only with each other but also with a growing base of digital audio sources such as iPods, mobile phones, and non-satellite digital radio.   XM and Sirius have both posted significant financial losses as they built up their programming lineups and recruited subscribers. Both stocks declined more than 40% last year on concerns about their continued growth in subscribers and softness in the retail market, but investors have held out hopes that a merger could bring costs down significantly.   Shareholders of XM and Sirius would each own approximately 50% of the combined company. XM shareholders would receive 4.6 shares of Sirius stock for each share of XM they own.   That would value XM shares at $17.02 each, based on Friday's closing prices, representing a premium of 22% from XM's closing value of $13.98 Friday. Markets were closed Monday for the Presidents Day holiday.   The companies didn't say what the new company would be called, though they described it as a merger of equals. The new company's board will have 12 members, including Parsons, Karmazin, four independent directors named by each company, and one representative each from General Motors Corp. (GM) and Honda Motor Co. (HMC).   News of a possible merger was reported earlier Monday by the New York Post.   On Friday, a Bear Stearns analyst said in a research note that a merger would have a good chance of overcoming regulatory obstacles.   Other analysts remain less sure. Sanford C. Bernstein analyst Craig Moffett said he gives the deal a "50-50" chance of passing regulatory muster.   Moffett said the deal could have a particularly tough time getting through the FCC, and is likely to opposed by the National Association of Broadcasters, a lobbying group that includes radio broadcasters. Moffett said it was "anyone's guess" as to whether the FCC would change its rule barring a consolidation of the two satellite radio companies.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 16:07 ET (21:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Vulcan Materials To Buy Florida Rock For $4.6B In Cash/Stk
Story: DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   Vulcan Materials Co. (VMC) on Monday said it agreed to acquire Florida Rock Industries Inc. (FRK) in a cash and stock deal worth about $4.6 billion.   The total blended cash and stock consideration of $68.03 a share, based on the closing price of Vulcan Materials' stock on Friday of $111.81 a share, represents a premium of 45% for Florida Rock shareholders based on the company's own closing stock price of $46.96 on Friday.   The deal, which should close in mid-year 2007, is expected to be neutral to Vulcan Materials' earnings this year and accretive next year and beyond.   Vulcan Materials also said it anticipates annual pretax cost synergies of about $50 million and expects the combined company to boast aggregate reserves totaling about 13.9 billion tons.   Goldman Sachs & Co. acted as financial adviser to Vulcan Materials while Lazard Freres & Co. acted as financial advisor to Florida Rock   Vulcan Materials plans to discuss the deal in a conference call Tuesday at 8:30 a.m. EST.     Order free Annual Report for Florida Rock Industries, Inc.  Visit http://djnewswires.ar.wilink.com/?link=FRK or call 1-888-301-0513  Order free Annual Report for Vulcan Materials Co.  Visit http://djnewswires.ar.wilink.com/?link=VMC or call 1-888-301-0513  (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 16:58 ET (21:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
