Headline: : Kraft Foods to Webcast Presentation at Consumer Analyst Group of New York Conference
Story: NORTHFIELD, Ill.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--February 19, 2007--   Kraft Foods Inc. (NYSE:KFT), a global leader in branded foods and beverages, will host a live audio webcast of the company's presentation at the annual Consumer Analyst Group of New York (CAGNY) Conference at www.kraft.com on Tuesday, February 20, 2007 at 12:45 pm ET. By logging on to www.kraft.com, listeners can both hear remarks by Irene Rosenfeld, Kraft CEO, as well as see the slides she shows at CAGNY.     During her presentation, Rosenfeld will present Kraft's comprehensive, three-year strategy to accelerate the company's growth and outline 2007 earnings guidance and the company's long-term financial outlook. Rosenfeld's presentation and question and answer session will be approximately one hour in length. Only CAGNY attendees will be able to ask questions, but listeners will be able to hear the question and answer session.     An archived rebroadcast and slides will be available on the company's website, www.kraft.com, for one year following the webcast.     Kraft Foods (NYSE:KFT) is one of the world's largest food and beverage companies. For more than 100 years, we've offered consumers delicious and wholesome foods that fit the way they live. Millions of times a day, in more than 150 countries, consumers reach for their favorite Kraft brands. Whether it's breakfast, lunch, dinner or a snack, consumers at home and on the go choose: Kraft cheeses, dinners and dressings; Oscar Mayer meats, DiGiorno pizzas, Oreo cookies, Ritz crackers and chips, Philadelphia cream cheese, Milka and Cote d'Or chocolates, Planters nuts, Honey Bunches of Oats cereals, Jacobs, Gevalia and Maxwell House coffees; Capri Sun, Crystal Light and Tang refreshment beverages; and a growing range of South Beach Diet and better-for-you Sensible Solution options. Headline: TALES OF THE TAPE: Nexstar Looks To Lead Local TV To Success
Story: By Shira Ovide     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     (This article was originally published Friday)     NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--After a long period in Wall Street's dog house, Nexstar Broadcasting Group Inc. (NXST) and other local TV companies are strutting like Best in Show winners.   Stocks of Nexstar, Lin TV Corp. (TVL), Young Broadcasting Inc. (YBTVA), Sinclair Broadcasting Group Inc. (SBGI) have climbed by 50% or better since last fall, as broadcasters squeeze cash from cable companies to carry the local stations on which Americans watch the majority of their television.   Nexstar has gotten credit for leading the crusade over the so-called retransmission fees, showering attention on the operator of 49 television stations in smaller markets like Erie, Pa., and Lubbock, Texas. In response, Nexstar's stock price has doubled since hitting a low of $3.50 in Oct. 24.   Shares traded recently at $7.44, down 5 cents, after earlier matching the 52-week high of $7.49. and the question for investors is whether shares have become overheated in the enthusiasm. Nexstar bulls say the market hasn't yet recognized Nexstar's other industry-leading positions: the company has pioneered the ownership of two television stations in the same market and by transforming its stations into TV-and-online machines, while much of the industry just starts to wake up to the Web.   To be sure, burgeoning revenue streams can't mask worries about an industry losing its privileged market position to the Internet and other media. Nexstar's uncomfortable debt load and low share float also makes any share swings - either up or down - magnified.   But local TV's believers are throwing their hat in with Nexstar, and retransmission fees are a key to growth at the Irving, Texas, company.   In 2005, Nexstar was among the first companies to stare down the cable operators over retransmission fees. In the fight, Nexstar pulled its networks from Cox Communications Inc. and Cable One Inc. in Missouri and other Nexstar markets, in some cases for nearly a year.   The cable networks eventually relented. From practically zero, Bear Stearns analyst Victor Miller estimates Nexstar ultimately could add $30 million - or about 11% of the company's estimated 2006 revenue - to its annual coffers from retransmission fees, which are essentially all profit.   "All else being equal, one should pay a higher multiple for those cash flows than from traditional advertising," said Jim Bell, a portfolio manager at Liberty Ridge Capital who oversees $1.4 million in Nexstar stock.   In addition, one of Nexstar's best assets is its expertise in so-called virtual duopolies. In a legal skirting of regulations blocking ownership of more than one TV station in small towns, more than two-thirds of Nexstar's revenue comes from 17 markets in which the company operates two stations through agreements with an independent entity.   "Perry Sook has done a very smart thing," said Elliot Evers of Media Venture Partners, referring to Nexstar's well respected chief executive. The duopoly condition gives Nexstar the market dominance to dictate ad prices and save money on sales staff and other operating expenses.   As traditional media struggles with the online shift of ad dollars and consumers, Nexstar also has been leading the charge into the Internet.   Less than a year ago, Nexstar lured Rajiv Lulla, a former Web guru at Viacom Inc.'s (VIA) MTV, to transform the company's online strategy. Starting last fall, eight Nexstar stations so far have beefed up their Web sites to carry more video content from the TV stations - especially local news - and sell advertising around it.   The company expects to convert the rest of its station group by this summer. So far, Lulla said, "Every single station is exceeding the best market that I could have imagined eight months ago.   The strategy pits Nexstar directly against local newspapers and Internet giants such as Yahoo Inc. (YHOO) and Google Inc. (GOOG), who are starting to compete fiercely for local ad dollars. But Sook, Nexstar's chief executive, says Nexstar has a leg up on its rivals thanks to an established relationship with local advertisers and TV viewers. "Google and Yahoo would love to have the local presence we have," Sook said.   Despite Nexstar's advantages, there are points of concern. Nexstar share price has climbed about 70% in the last year, but hasn't approached the November 2003 IPO price of $14.   "There are some good things going on in the industry," said Evers. "Does Nexstar have a likelihood of passing beyond the peer group? I think not."   One problem is the inexorable decline in market share for local advertising dollars, which the affiliates rely on for the bulk of its revenue. Meanwhile, Nexstar's debt stands out, even in a leveraged industry.   The company's total debt stood at about $640 million at Sept. 30, and although Nexstar has pledged to sell assets to reudce debt, it hasn't done so yet. Nexstar has said it is committed to tidying its balance sheet and expects to end the year leveraged under 7.5 times earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, or Ebitda. The debt of the local TV group ranges from about 3 to 8 times Ebtida.   Despite worries, Nexstar could still be undervalued. Private-equity money is flowing into local TV, creating a floor on shares above where Nexstar and other public operators are trading.   Miller recently estimated Nexstar is valued at about 10.1 times estimated 2007 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, while private equity recently acquired TV stations from New York Times Co. (NYT) and CBS Corp. (CBS) for an estimated 13 to 15 times Ebitda.   "I think you could still see some expansion in the equity," Bell said. Assuming things stay pretty favorable in terms for their results and economic conditions, he said, "Another couple of dollars [a share] wouldn't surprise me."   (Shira Ovide covers the media and marketing industries for Dow Jones Newswires.)   -By Shira Ovide, Dow Jones Newswires; 201-938-5287; shira.ovide@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 07:30 ET (12:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Walgreen Co. Announces Store Operations Promotions
Story: DEERFIELD, Ill.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--February 19, 2007--   Walgreen Co. (NYSE: WAG)(NASDAQ: WAG) today promoted Debra M. Ferguson to senior vice president of store operations and Suzanne M. Hansen to vice president of store operations.     Ferguson, previously a store operations vice president for the company, is replacing Barry L. Markl, who is retiring at the end of March after a 40-year career with Walgreens. "Over his career, Barry has taught that integrity, honesty and attitude are the basis of the Walgreen culture, and how important that culture is to our success," said Walgreens President and CEO Jeffrey A. Rein. "We wish Barry and his family all the best in his retirement."     Ferguson began her Walgreens career in 1985 as an assistant store manager in Colorado Springs, Colo. She was named a district manager in 1997 and promoted to a vice president of store operations in 2002. Ferguson received a B.S. degree in business management from Roger Williams University, Bristol, R.I., in 2006.     "Debbie has an exceptional ability to listen well to people at all levels," said Rein. "She's passionate about our business, sees the big picture and is willing to take risks."     Replacing Ferguson as a vice president of store operations is Suzanne M. Hansen. She joined Walgreens as a pharmacy intern in Sioux City, Iowa, in 1992 while attending South Dakota State University, where she graduated with a pharmacy degree in 1995. She was promoted to district pharmacy supervisor in 2000 and district manager in 2004.     "Suzanne has great people skills, and her years in pharmacy give her particular empathy for both our pharmacists and our patients," said Rein.     Walgreen Co. is the nation's largest drugstore chain with fiscal 2006 sales of $47.4 billion. The company operates 5,611 stores in 48 states and Puerto Rico, including 76 Happy Harry's drugstores in Delaware and surrounding states. Walgreens also provides additional services to pharmacy patients and prescription drug and medical plans through Walgreens Health Services, its managed care division, which includes Walgreens Health Initiatives Inc. (a pharmacy benefits manager), Walgreens Mail Service Inc., Walgreens Home Care Inc. and Walgreens Specialty Pharmacy.        CONTACT: Walgreen Co.               Michael Polzin, 847-914-2925               Internet: http://www.walgreens.com        SOURCE: Walgreen Co. Headline: Halley Family Stake In Carrefour Was On Sale- Newspaper
Story: PARIS (Dow Jones)-- The Halley family's 13% stake in French retailer Carrefour (12017.FR) was at one time put up for sale on markets in London and Paris, according to French newspaper La Tribune on Monday, without any detail regarding the timing of the offer.   The Halley family's stake in the world's second largest retailer is currently valued at EUR4.5 billion.   In July last year, talks of a possible sale by the Halley family, Carrefour's largest shareholder, already circulated on markets but were denied by Carrefour at the time.   Last week, the Halley family said it decided to name Bernard Bontoux as head of the family group, replacing Luc Vandevelde.   "The Halley family outlines the importance of its stake in Carrefour and reaffirms, at this time, its care for the company and its shareholders' interests," the Halley family said in a statement at the time.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.latribune.fr     -By Paris Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 33-1-4017 1740     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 01:27 ET (06:27 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: BT Appoints KPMG's Rake As New Chairman
Story: By Daniel Thomas   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     LONDON (Dow Jones)--U.K. telecommunications operator BT Group PLC (BT) Monday said accountant Sir Michael Rake will replace Sir Christopher Bland as its new chairman in September.   Bland announced in 2003 that he would retire from his post at BT this September. During his tenure as BT chairman Bland has played a crucial role in turning around the fortunes of the former telecommunications monopoly.   Rake, currently chairman of accountancy firm KPMG International, is being brought in to boost the management board's international business experience, something BT is trying to do as it builds its networked IT services unit BT Global Services.   As chairman of KPMG International, 59-year old Rake presides over a $17 billion global fee income and operations in 148 countries. Rake has spent 33 years at KPMG.   Bland, a former chairman of the British Broadcasting Corp. board of governors, became BT's chairman on May 1. 2001. Bland played an instrumental role in reducing BT's debt levels and appointed current Chief Executive Ben Verwaayen - who has moved the business away from one that is reliant on voice call revenues to a business offering internet and corporate IT services.   Analysts believe Bland has done a very good job over the past six years.   "Bland will be a hard act to follow," said Morten Singleton, telecommunications analyst at WestLB.   "I am excited at the prospect of working together with (Rake) at BT. We have accomplished a great deal, but there is still much more work to be done building BT's global presence and ensuring that the UK stays at the forefront of the broadband revolution," said Verwaayen.   At 1515 GMT, shares in BT were trading down 1.5 pence, or 0.5, at 315.5 pence.   Company Web site: http://www.btplc.com   -By Daniel Thomas, Dow Jones Newswires; 44-20-7842-9264; dan.thomas@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 10:20 ET (15:20 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Canada Bonds End Narrowly Mixed In Trade Thinned By US Holiday
Story: TORONTO (Dow Jones)--Canadian bonds ended narrowly mixed with prices in most maturities hovering on both sides of unchanged Monday, as the close of U.S. markets for Presidents Day deprived the market of direction and kept overall activity minimal.   Traders said there was some modest initial selling pressure from early news that Canadian wholesale trade unexpectedly surged 2.7% to C$42.82 billion (US$36.82 billion) for the largest monthly gain in nearly three years.   The data may have reinforced the concern initiated by other recent strong Canadian data releases that economic growth was already accelerating in late 2006 and setting up for a robust first quarter 2007 rebound.   In keeping with Monday's thinly-traded and illiquid environment, however, bond prices quickly returned to generally neutral levels, though data due later in the week could keep Canadian bonds under some pressure.   Fixed-income strategist Mark Chandler of RBC Capital Markets in Toronto said in a commentary Monday that "a broader picture is beginning to shape up that suggests Canadian bond markets may under-perform."   "An improving trade balance, continued strength in real manufacturing shipments and an improvement in wholesale trade suggest that activity ended the year solidly," Chandler said, adding that the approach of the Canadian government's budget announcement and the strong possibility of federal and Quebec elections sometime this spring could also lead to risk aversion and serve to limit the potential upside for the bond market.   The next key events for bonds will be Tuesday's Canadian January consumer price index report, followed by December retail sales and the U.S. January CPI, both on Wednesday.   The consensus estimate is for Canada's all-items CPI to to rise 0.1% month-on-month and 1.3% year-over-year in January, with core inflation seen up 0.2% month-on-month.   -By Paul Evans; Dow Jones Newswires; (416) 306-2022; paulr.evans@dowjones.com       (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 14:55 ET (19:55 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: New York-To-Atlantic City Express Train May Skip Jersey Stops
Story: NEWARK, N.J. (AP)--New Jersey's gambling mecca will soon be more easily accessible by rail - but not if you live in New Jersey.   The 2 1/2-hour express train service from New York to Atlantic City, scheduled to begin in late 2007 or early 2008, has no planned stops here.   Details are being finalized for the new service, dubbed "ACES" for Atlantic City Express Service. But in the current scenario, the trains would run nonstop from New York to just north of Philadelphia, then head east and continue nonstop to Atlantic City.   Auggie Cipollini, senior vice president and chief administrative officer of the Borgata Hotel Casino & Spa, said a stop in New Jersey is still possible.   "We're still open to it," Cipollini said. "It's something we're going to have to partner with NJ Transit to see whether or not that's feasible."   The casinos are making the decisions because they are paying for the new train service. A joint venture involving the Borgata, Caesars Atlantic City Hotel Casino and Harrah's Atlantic City is buying eight double-level cars for approximately $15 million, and the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority will lease four locomotives for another $4.5 million.   The casinos want to penetrate the New York City market, specifically 20- and 30-somethings with disposable income who may have balked in the past at the idea of riding a bus to Atlantic City.   Under the current proposal, the service would operate on the weekends, with two departures planned from New York on Friday and one from Atlantic City. Four trains would leave from each destination on Saturday and three would depart Atlantic City on Sunday.   Fares have not been finalized, according to Cipollini, but he said they will be competitive with Amtrak's Acela service between New York and Philadelphia, which currently costs between $76 and $112 each way.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 16:30 ET (21:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Savanna Energy Acquires Well Servicing And Rental Businesses>SVY.T
Story: CALGARY, Feb. 19 /CNW/ - Savanna Energy Services Corp. ("Savanna") (TSX: SVY) is pleased to announce the acquisition of the assets of a privately-held well servicing company, and the shares of a related well servicing and rental business for aggregate proceeds of $67.8 Million, consisting of $50.8 Million in cash and $17 million of Savanna common shares. The Savanna common shares issued pursuant to the transaction will be placed in escrow and released over a 3-year period.    The combined acquisitions include 20 service rigs plus associated field locations, boilers and support equipment, as well as 1 additional service rig under construction. The acquisition increases Savanna's current well servicing fleet by 83% to 44 rigs.    The operational focus for the purchased equipment is primarily in east central Alberta and west central Saskatchewan, areas in which Savanna does not currently operate. The majority of the fleet of service rigs was built in the last 4 years, and the purchase includes a manufacturing, maintenance and repair facility and personnel that will be used to support the entire go-forward Savanna well-servicing fleet.    All of the principles have agreed to remain with Savanna in their present roles, and all have executed independent three year employment and non-competition agreements.    Based on normalized 2006 estimated results, the acquisition is valued at less than 4 times earnings before interest, income taxes, depreciation and amortization ("EBITDA").    Post this transaction, Savanna's well servicing fleet will consist of 44 rigs, with 8 rigs scheduled for manufacture and delivery in 2007.    This transaction reinforces Savanna's growing position in the well servicing market in a production-oriented area of the basin, and adds significant additional scale to the core well servicing business to complement Savanna's strong existing drilling presence.    Savanna Energy Services Corp. is a leading North American contract drilling and oilfield services company providing a broad range of drilling, well servicing and related services with a focus on fit for purpose technologies for the North American market and industry-leading aboriginal relationships. Post this transaction Savanna will operate 87 drilling rigs, 44 well servicing rigs and 8 coil service units in Canada and the United States.    This Report contains forward looking statements which reflect management's expectations regarding the Company's future growth, results of operations, performance and business prospects and opportunities. Wherever possible, words such as "believe", "expect" and similar expressions have been used to identify these forward looking statements. Headline: : Corrected: Verizon to Expand Its Fiber-Optic Network to 59,000 Additional Homes in Portland, Ore., Metro Area
Story: Forest Grove, McMinnville and Wilsonville to join other Oregon Communities Getting Company's Industry-Leading Fiber-to-the-Premises Network       BEAVERTON, Ore., Feb. 19 /PRNewswire/ -- Editors are advised this is a corrected version of the release issued earlier today.  Some of the pricing in the original release was inaccurate.  Complete, corrected release follows:     Internet users in Washington, Clackamas, Multnomah and Yamhill counties will soon be able to subscribe to state-of-the-art broadband service from Verizon, the company that is building the nation's most advanced digital all- fiber-optic network.  On Monday (Feb. 19) Verizon announced plans to deploy the advanced fiber-optic technology all the way to customers' homes and businesses in those four counties.     The company said it will extend its fiber-to-the premises (FTTP) network this year to the communities of Forest Grove, McMinnville and Wilsonville. It also will continue its network expansion in the Beaverton, Sherwood and Tualatin areas of Washington County, and the east Multnomah communities of Gresham, Troutdale, Fairview and Wood Village.     A total of 59,000 additional homes will be connected to the FTTP network, which offers the fastest data speeds available to homeowners and small businesses and is capable of offering TV services in the future.  Below are the number of households in each community that will be added to the network:          Community            Households      Forest Grove            9,600      Gresham Area           15,700      McMinnville             5,000      Wilsonville             4,300      Beaverton              14,700      Sherwood                2,500      Tualatin                6,000      Unincorporated          1,200       The network uses hair-thin strands of fiber and optical electronics to directly link homes and businesses to Verizon's network and replaces the traditional copper-wire connections for voice, high-speed Internet and TV.     "The FTTP project already has had a positive impact on the local economy, creating new jobs," said David S. Valdez, the company's vice president for the Northwest.  "We've employed hundreds of contractors to build the network; and we've hired more than 300 new Verizon employees over the past two years to design the network, install our FiOS broadband and voice services, and provide technical support to our customers.     "More importantly, however, Verizon is offering consumers a choice by providing the best network available at a competitive price for voice, data and, eventually, TV," he added.  Recently, the Metropolitan Area Communications Commission board of directors recommended adoption of a video franchise agreement for Verizon to provide its FiOS TV service to Washington County communities.     Verizon expects to install more than 5 million feet of fiber-optic cabling throughout the Portland metro area by year-end 2007, bringing to 211,000 the total number of homes and small businesses in the area that will be linked to the new network.     More than 6 million homes and businesses in parts of 16 states are now passed by Verizon's all-fiber network, and the company expects its new network to pass about 18 million premises by the end of 2010.  Verizon had 687,000 FiOS (FYE'-ose) Internet customers and 207,000 FiOS TV customers by year-end 2006.     FiOS Internet service is offered in more than 1,600 communities in the 16 states where the company's new network is deployed: California, Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Indiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Texas, Virginia and Washington.  The company currently offers FiOS TV service in parts of ten states: California, Delaware, Florida, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Texas and Virginia.     Fiber offers tremendous advantages to network operators, in addition to new and superior services for customers.  For example, fiber offers reliable service in stretches of wet weather that can affect copper-based networks.     "Verizon's 100 percent fiber-optic network is technically superior to other communication platforms because it offers faster data speeds than those currently available, as well as voice and video capabilities," said Vickie Curry, Verizon's director of customer operations in the Northwest. "This new network will have greater reliability and lower maintenance costs. By deploying fiber to homes and businesses in our territory, Verizon is transforming its wireline business into 21st century technology."              Customer Feedback About Verizon Fiber Service Is Positive     Customer reaction to Verizon's FiOS service has been very positive, with broadband subscribers rapidly increasing in markets across the country. Verizon will notify customers in Washington when FiOS is available locally.     "FiOS has been an extraordinary hit with our customers," said Curry. "People are literally lining up to get what they know is a fantastic service at an excellent price. The need for speed and ability to take advantage of bandwidth-intensive applications remain a top priority for all computer users."     There are three tiers of Verizon FiOS Internet service for consumers, with downstream (download) speeds of up to 5, 15, and 30 Mbps (megabits per second)*:          -- 5 Mbps downstream and 2 Mbps upstream. Suited for Internet surfing and         basic computer functions. $39.99 a month.        -- 15 Mbps downstream and 2 Mbps upstream. Appealing to families that have         multiple computers and various needs such as media downloads and the         ability to access or share large files. $49.99 a month.        -- 30 Mbps downstream and 5 Mbps upstream. Designed for communications-         intensive power users with significant bandwidth needs, such as         telecommuters or work-at-home households and avid online gamers.         $179.95 a month with a one-year agreement.       Each consumer data offer includes: state-of-the-art, wireless broadband home router; Verizon's Surround entertainment portal optimized for high-speed access featuring news, games, streaming video and more; virtually unlimited 2 GB (gigabytes) of e-mail capacity with up to 9 e-mail accounts; 24/7 live technical support; and 30-day money-back guarantee.     The FTTP initiative represents a natural extension of the more than 10 million miles of fiber-optic cable Verizon already has in place and extends the high capacity, speed and quality of fiber directly to the customer's doorstep.  With FTTP technology, Verizon can easily add more capacity, higher speeds or video services in the future.     Verizon's digital subscriber line (DSL) service will remain the company's most widely available form of high-speed Internet access for the foreseeable future while the company ramps up FTTP deployment.  The company offers DSL on a widespread basis throughout Oregon over existing copper lines at speeds of up to 3 Mbps.        *NOTE: Actual (throughput) speeds will vary.     Verizon Communications Inc. (NYSE: VZ), headquartered in New York, is a leader in delivering broadband and other wireline and wireless communication innovations to mass market, business, government and wholesale customers. Verizon Wireless operates America's most reliable wireless network, serving more than 59 million customers nationwide.  Verizon's Wireline operations include Verizon Business, which operates one of the most expansive wholly owned global IP networks, and Verizon Telecom, which is deploying the nation's most advanced fiber-optic network to deliver the benefits of converged communications, information and entertainment services to customers.  A Dow 30 company, Verizon has a diverse workforce of approximately 242,000 and last year generated consolidated operating revenues of more than $88 billion.  For more information, visit http://www.verizon.com.     VERIZON'S ONLINE NEWS CENTER: Verizon news releases, executive speeches and biographies, media contacts, high quality video and images, and other information are available at Verizon's News Center on the World Wide Web at http://www.verizon.com/news.  To receive news releases by e-mail, visit the News Center and register for customized automatic delivery of Verizon news releases    SOURCE  Verizon       /CONTACT: Kevin Laverty, +1-425-261-5855, kevin.laverty@verizon.com      /Web site: http://www.verizon.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 16:20 ET (21:20 GMT)

Headline: : Ibis Technology Announces Live Webcast of Fourth Quarter and Fiscal Year 2006 Results Conference Call Thursday, February 22, 2007, at 5:00 p.m. ET
Story: DANVERS, Mass.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--February 19, 2007--   Ibis Technology (Nasdaq: IBIS), a leading provider of SIMOX-SOI implantation equipment to the worldwide semiconductor industry, today announced that the Company plans to conduct a conference call on Thursday, February 22, 2007 at 5:00 p.m. Eastern Time to discuss results for the fourth quarter and fiscal year ended December 31, 2006.     The dial-in number to listen to the conference call by telephone is (719) 457-2679. In addition, a live audio webcast of the conference call will be available at the Ibis Technology website at www.ibis.com or at www.streetevents.com. For those who cannot listen to the live broadcast, a replay of the call will be available on these websites for approximately three weeks.       About Ibis Technology     Ibis Technology Corporation is a leading provider of oxygen implanters for the production of SIMOX-SOI (Separation-by-Implantation-of-Oxygen Silicon-On-Insulator) wafers for the worldwide semiconductor industry. Headquartered in Danvers, Massachusetts, the company maintains an additional office in Aptos, California. Ibis Technology is traded on the Nasdaq National Market under the symbol IBIS. Headline: SmartMoney(3/1) Tech Stocks: Finding A Pulse
Story: (From SMARTMONEY)     By Megan Barnett   [After seven years on life support, technology stocks are finally showing some healthy vital signs. Why the rebound is for  real this time, and how to play it: five stocks and two funds.]     It was March 2000, and Richard Parower had just taken a job as a technology analyst for Seligman funds. Little did he know that his universe was about to implode. Over the next two years, tech stocks went nowhere but down, and assets in the Seligman Global Technology fund fell to $377 million from $1.2 billion at the height of the boom. "It was a very painful period," he says. "There was no way to know when it was going to stop." Parower stuck it out, however, taking over as coman-ager of the fund in 2002. And coming off last year's 18.6 percent return, he says he's finally getting over the shell shock of the tech bust.   After seven long years, investors are finally dipping their toes back into tech. Shares of technology bellwethers like Microsoft and Cisco Systems shot up more than 30 percent in the final months of 2006, after years in the doghouse. And the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite index, which fell 17 percent in a selloff last spring, staged a rebound to close out 2006 up 10 percent. Savvy investors believe this could just be the start, thanks to a confluence of factors, including the sluggish economy and slowing corporate profit growth. "You combat a slowdown by increasing your efficiencies and productivity," says Brian Belski, chief U.S. sector strategist for Merrill Lynch. "You do that by investing in technology." Indeed, the New York Stock Exchange found in its annual survey of chief executives that more than three in five expect to increase corporate IT spending in 2007.   Other catalysts bode well for the sector. Microsoft is finally rolling out Vista, its first new operating system in more than five years, and both hardware and software analysts expect the release will unlock some of the corporate tech dollars that have been pent up in anticipation of its unveiling. And remember the vast investment in servers and storage in advance of Y2K? Much of that equipment is due for an upgrade, notes David Bianco, chief U.S. equity strategist at UBS. Even the weak dollar works to tech's advantage. Semiconductor giant Intel, for example, derives 85 percent of its revenue from overseas. The more the dollar falls, the cheaper it is for foreign firms to buy U.S. goods.   To be sure, investing in tech stocks requires a high tolerance for volatility. Recently, the group got clobbered by (and has since bounced back from) the options-backdating scandals. Another common hazard: The price for tech goods is constantly falling, so companies have to sell increasingly more stuff just to stay even. Nor is there a consensus on Wall Street that tech spending is on the rise. While Merrill Lynch expects it to accelerate, Goldman Sachs is predicting that IT spending growth will slow.   One thing not in dispute: Large-cap tech stocks tend to be debt free, and many generate growing piles of cash. According to Standard & Poor's, earnings for the tech sector are expected to grow more than 21 percent this year, while the forecast for the overall market is less than 10 percent. Nor is tech tied to the slowing U.S. economy. "We're still very early on in global Internet- penetration rates," says Larry Puglia, who manages the T. Rowe Price Blue Chip Growth fund. And expanding Internet access around the globe creates demand for more software, chips, servers and networking equipment.   To find the five stocks in our tech portfolio, we polled money managers and analysts and probed the various sectors within the group, from software and semiconductors to hardware and networking equipment. And because we wanted a diverse group of undervalued companies with strong fundamentals and growth prospects, we stayed away from the tech stars of 2006, including Cisco, Apple and Google, focusing instead on unloved stocks that we think have more upside potential.     Intel (INTC, $21)   CHIPMAKER INTEL IS like a heavyweight-boxing champ in the sixth round against an opponent who was supposed to go down with the first punch. The competitor in Intel's case is Advanced Micro Devices, and although the match has been bloody at times, it's far from over. Intel had long dominated the market for microprocessors, until AMD beat it to market with a series of chips starting in 2003 that were widely considered superior to Intel's offerings. After losing market share, the Santa Clara, Calif.-based firm slashed prices to reduce its bloated inventory; it also cut costs by $2 billion, selling off underperforming businesses and scaling back its workforce.   The result is a leaner organization with renewed drive. Indeed, late last year the firm regained an edge over AMD with the release of a faster chip for desktop computers. Nevertheless, the company's woes  have kept its stock mired in the low $20s for the past year. Analysts expect Intel to earn $6.4 billion, or $1.09 a share, this year on revenue of $38.1 billion, giving the company a forward P/E of 19, which is well below the semiconductor industry's forward P/E of 25. "They've really been focused on margin recovery," says Dan Genter, president of money-management firm RNC Genter. "We like it at the current price." He's not alone. Banc of America Securities analyst Sumit Dhanda recently raised his 12-month target price to $28, up 33 percent from where it trades today.     F5 Networks (FFIV, $79)   "SERVER TOO BUSY." Those three little words may be frustrating for Internet users, but for the Web sites, an unavailable page translates into lost revenue. A site's information lives on a cluster of servers; each time you click on a link, your request is routed to one of them. Congestion happens when too many requests are routed to a single server. That's where F5 comes in. The company's networking software balances the load between servers-no small job considering that some of its clients (think Microsoft and Bank of America) have 10,000 servers or more.   The stock chart for the Seattle-based company looks like a snapshot of the dotcom era. The company's shares came public in 1999 at $10 and quickly shot to $156, before crashing back down to $4. But unlike many of the dot-com darlings, F5 not only survived, but grew into a very profitable business. This year F5 is expected to earn $86 million, or $2.54 a share, on revenue of $507 million. That's not to say there haven't been problems. Last year F5 got caught up in the options-back-dating scandal and came within a stone's throw of being delisted from the Nasdaq. But Susan Kalla, an independent portfolio manager who has followed the networking sector for more than a decade, likes F5's ability to maintain predictable margins and generate cash. "It's a hyper growth company with not much competition," she says. And as a pure play -- most of its competitors have been bought by the likes of Cisco and Juniper Networks -- F5 has a leg up on the big guys in terms of innovation.   Troy Jensen, networking analyst for Piper Jaffray, is equally enthusiastic. He expects the company's revenue and earnings to grow at 30 percent a year for the next three years; his 12-month price target is $100.     EMC (EMC, $14)   OVER THE PAST THREE years, data-storage firm EMC has spent more than $6 billion gobbling up 21 smaller companies in the data-management business, including RSA Security and Documentum. And throughout that time, the Hopkinton, Mass.-based firm has been in a perpetual state of restructuring, shedding staff in some areas while continuing to hire in others. The new streamlined EMC, which should earn $1.4 billion, or 63 cents a share, on revenue of $12.6 billion this year, bills itself as more than just a data-storage company. It promises to help companies secure, sort and manage data as well as store it. The shift includes greater emphasis on software sales, which have the added benefit of producing  higher margins than its hardware offerings.   Today EMC, which has seen its shares bounce between $10 and $15 for the past three years, looks primed for gains. Parower of the Seligman Funds likes the fact that the company "still has a pile of cash" after all of its acquisitions. (EMC took on $2.2 billion in debt to finance the RSA purchase, but with its $2.7 billion in cash and marketable securities on its balance sheet, it has a comfortable cushion.) Another convert to the stock, UBS hardware analyst Benjamin Reitzes, recently upgraded the shares, concluding that its three-year strategy should start paying off in earnest. Though the stock trades at a pricey 22 times estimated 2007 earnings estimates, those earnings are expected to grow by 21 percent a year for the next five years, according to Zacks's poll of Wall Street analysts.     Autodesk (ADSK, $44)   IN EMERGING MARKETS, the pipes are being laid, and the streets are being paved. In the U.S., our skylines are being redrawn, and landscaped office parks populate the suburbs. All of which plays to the strength of software maker Autodesk. The San Rafael, Calif.-based firm makes computer-aided design software, which is used by designers and engineers to create plans for everything from skyscrapers and sewers to espresso makers and auto assembly-line machines.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 06:03 ET (11:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: THE SKEPTIC: Giving Total A Royal Bashing
Story: (This story was originally published Friday)       By Anne-Sylvaine Chassany     A DOW JONES NEWSWIRES COLUMN     PARIS (Dow Jones)--Bashing oil producer Total isn't new in France.   But it's reached new heights ahead of the upcoming presidential elections in May.   It has its roots in a long-held tradition in France of distrusting, if not despising, large privately-held companies - particularly if they make a profit.   Perverse as that sounds in the 21st Century, French Socialist presidential candidate Segolene Royal has taken to this old habit with gusto.   France's largest company by market value is making too much money and should be punished for it, Royal says. If she wins, she would force the oil major to share its "insulting", "incredible" profits, through a special windfall tax, she says.   The attack underscores the populist side to Royal, as well as her ignorance on business matters, to say nothing of poor math.   First, raising taxes on Total would have little impact on the French government's budget.   French corporate levy - at 33.33% of taxable profit- is levied on profits generated by a company's operations in the country.   Unfortunately for Royal, Total is a global business. And there's not much crude oil to be found in France. The company makes only 5% to 6% of its profit at home, through refining, marketing and chemicals units.   Total's pretax profit in France was around EUR1.6 billion in 2006, according to the company's Chairman Thierry Desmarest, a small fraction of the EUR24 billion pretax profit reported by the company Wednesday.   Indeed, Royal's super-tax would miss the bulk of Total's profits from its thriving exploration and production activities, but add to the current difficulties at the company's low-margin operations in France - hardly good for jobs or future investment.   She's clearly not asked herself the question why Total's main rivals Royal Dutch Shell and Exxon Mobil are exiting the French refining sector. It's unlikely to be because the business is flourishing.   Royal's attacks against Total may simply end up giving ideas to those who can legitimately demand a piece of Total's oil wealth: the oil-and-gas producing countries.   Like its peers, Total is already facing nationalist pressure in those countries keen to gain more control over their domestic resources amid high hydrocarbon prices.   In Venezuela, the French oil major is trying to prevent the government from nationalizing its heavy oil Sincor project in the Orinoco Valley. It had to negotiate new contract terms with Bolivia and is facing constant criticism from the Russian government on the way it operates a small oil field in the Nenets region.   The pressure is visible in Total's tax bill. The company paid EUR13.7 billion taxes in 2006. The effective tax rate in the upstream division increased to 62.1% in the fourth quarter of 2006, from 59.4% on average in 2005.   The citizens of Venezuela and other oil-producing countries might be better off as a result of that, but you can be sure it's had no impact on France. French investors have nonetheless stand to share some of the EUR4 billion in dividends Total plans to pay out of its 2006 earnings.   Of course, higher foreign taxes are weighing on the prospects of a French company that's a testament to the success of French multinationals in recent years - something you would have thought an economic patriot like Royal should be celebrating, not sanctioning.      (Anne-Sylvaine Chassany has financial news reporter since 2001. She has reported the energy sector and merger and acquisitions in France for Dow Jones Newswires 2005. She can be reached at +331 4017 1754 or by e-mail: anne-sylvaine.chassany@dowjones.com)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 01:45 ET (06:45 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE: Algeria Approves First Calgary's $1.3B MLE Devt
Story: By Kaveri Niththyananthan   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     LONDON (Dow Jones)--London- and Toronto-listed First Calgary Petroleums Ltd. (FPL.LN) Monday announced that the Algerian government has approved its $1.3 billion MLE oil and gas field development plan on Block 405b in the Berkine Basin.   First Calgary obtained the block in 2001, and the approval marks a milestone for planned commercialization of the project, Chief Financial Officer John van der Welle said.   "This is only the first stage, with considerable potential for the entire block," van der Welle said.   At 1104 GMT, First Calgary shares were up 1.74%, or 5 pence, at 292.5 pence.   First Calgary will fund 75% of the development costs, with its partner Sonatrach, an Algerian government-owned company, picking up the remaining 25%.   First Calgary will only take 27.7% of profits, however, with Sonatrach taking the rest once the project comes on stream in late 2009.   "It is all about the value of the project and the costs related to revenue," van der Welle said.   However, concerns arose regarding an upcoming windfall tax. Tony Alves, analyst at KBC Peel Hunt, said, "We have not yet taken this into account in our economics. It will clearly reduce the value."   Van der Welle said, "We won't be paying any taxes other than a one-off 5% tax, which will not come into effect until we start production."   This 5% rate applies to First Calgary's production share of 20,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day or less. It rises in steps to a maximum of 50%, however, if the company's production share exceeds 100,000 boe/d. However the total period of time over which the tax will be applied is still being decided upon, a spokesman for First Calgary said.   In December, the Algerian government published a further decree to the initial windfall tax announcement, which said the new tax would apply when the monthly average Brent oil price exceeds $30 per barrel.   The cost of development, which includes an expanded gas plant capacity to treat up to 460 million cubic feet of raw gas per day and field gathering facilities, will be incurred between 2007 and 2009.   The company estimates that these facilities will process 230 million cubic feet of raw gas per day on a gross basis and associated natural gas liquids and oil. As part of an agreement signed in November 2006, Sonatrach will market the total natural gas production from Block 405b.   There are no commercial arrangements on the sale of liquid gas production, though First Calgary said it will sell its share at world market prices.   The company estimates initial gross MLE field reserves to be developed and recovered to be 1.3 trillion cubic feet of gas equivalent reserves, or approximately 230 million boe.   This is compared to estimates of 3.9 trillion cubic feet of 2P, or probable gas equivalent reserves, estimated for the entire Block 405b as at Dec. 31, 2005.   In 2006, the company asked petroleum consultants DeGolyer & MacNaughton to conduct a review with findings expected to be released in March.   Dry gas and liquids, or oil, condensates and liquefied petroleum gas will each represent 50% of total MLE production revenues.   First Calgary expects to produce 200 million cubic feet per day of dry gas at the MLE field in the first 10 years, along with liquids of 21,000 barrels per day.   The plant, production and field gathering facilities will expand to accommodate any additional production, of up to 400 million cubic feet per day of dry gas and associated natural gas liquids and oil.   KBC Peel Hunt's Alves said, "The development approval is clearly a milestone for the project and the company but only serves to highlight once again that the shares are seriously overvalued."  He has a sell rating on the company.     Company Web site: http://www.fcpl.ca.     -By Kaveri Niththyananthan, Dow Jones Newswires; 4420 7842 9299; kaveri.niththyananthan@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 06:44 ET (11:44 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Lundin Mining Informs On The Accident In The Galmoy Mine In Ireland>LUN.T
Story: VANCOUVER, BRITISH COLUMBIA--(CCNMatthews - Feb. 18, 2007) - (TSX:LUN)(AMEX:LMC)(SSE:LUMI) Lundin Mining Corporation ("Lundin Mining" or the "Company") deeply regrets to have to announce that the serious accident which occurred in the Galmoy mine, owned by Lundin Mining, in Ireland on Friday the 16th of February 2007, led to a fatality.    A mine fitter, Michael Joyce, fell through a safety railing while working near the crusher and sustained serious head injuries. On Sunday afternoon, the 18th of February 2007, he passed way.    Michael, aged 43, was employed by Galmoy Mines Ltd. in 2000. He leaves his wife Eileen and two young children.    "The accident is foremost a tragedy for Michael's family. Michael had been working in the mine for nearly seven years and was a well respected colleague and work mate. The loss of Michael is deeply regretted by the management and staff at the mine.    We will thoroughly investigate the cause of this accident in conjunction with the Health and Safety Authority. On this day our thoughts are with Michael's wife, Eileen, and their two small children, as well as the family circle," said Stefan Mansson, Managing Director at Galmoy Mines Ltd.    Operations at the Galmoy mine will be at a stand-still until after the funeral.                     FOR FURTHER INFORMATION PLEASE CONTACT:             Lundin Mining Corporation           Catarina Ihre           Manager Corporate Communications           +46 70 607 9263           Website: www.lundinmining.com           or           Galmoy Mines Ltd.           Stefan Mansson           Managing Director           +353 56 8837 122     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 06:23 ET (11:23 GMT)

Headline: : Somerset Entertainment Income Fund Declares Cash Distribution>SOM.UN.T
Story: TORONTO, ONTARIO--(CCNMatthews - Feb. 19, 2007) - Somerset Entertainment Income Fund (TSX:SOM.UN) announced today a cash distribution of 5.0 cents per unit for the period from February 1, 2007 to February 28, 2007, to be paid March 15, 2007 to holders of record of units of the Fund at the close of business on February 28, 2007.    The Fund's policy is for unitholders of record on the last business day of a calendar month to receive distributions during the fifteen days following.    About Somerset Entertainment Income Fund    Somerset is the leading North American producer and distributor of specialty music sold internationally through non-traditional retailers using interactive displays. The company's extensive distribution network includes mass merchants, specialty chains and independent gift stores in more than 20 countries, including the United States and Canada. Based in Toronto, Canada, the company employs over 150 people at offices in Toronto, Ontario (Canada); Buffalo Grove, Illinois, and Minneapolis, Minnesota, (U.S.A.); and Essex, England (UK). Headline: EARNINGS PREVIEW: Allianz 4Q Net Pft Seen +43% At EUR1.25B
Story: By Ulrike Dauer     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     FRANKFURT (Dow Jones)--German insurer Allianz SE (AZ) will report a 43% rise in fourth-quarter net profit Thursday, helped by low disaster claims and restructuring and efficiency improvements in most units, analysts said.   A tax rebate due to a change in German corporate tax law and the full ownership of its Italian unit RAS Holding SpA (R.MI) will also add to fourth-quarter earnings, while restructuring costs for Dresdner Bank will partly erase those benefits, analysts said.   Six analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswires on average forecast Allianz to book a net profit of EUR1.25 billion in the October-to-December period, up from EUR872 million in the year-ago period.   Fourth-quarter operating profit is expected to rise 17% to EUR2.24 billion from EUR1.91 billion, on total revenue of EUR24.8 billion, down 2% from EUR25.2 billion.   For the full year, the analysts on average expect a net-profit increase of 56% to EUR6.8 billion from EUR4.4 billion. The 2006 operating profit is expected to rise 29% to EUR10.3 billion from EUR8 billion.   Analysts expect the full-year earnings to top Allianz's own company guidance of net profit above EUR6 billion and operating profit above EUR9.5 billion.   The figures are due Thursday, but in the past Allianz has surprised markets with an early earnings release.   Allianz has said that the full ownership of RAS at the end of the fourth quarter will add between EUR40 million and EUR45 million to the group's net profit in the last quarter.   At the end of the third quarter, Allianz owned 76.33% of RAS but said it plans to reach full ownership in the fourth quarter.   Allianz has also said that its 2006 net profit will be boosted by a EUR500 million tax rebate as part of a new version of Germany's corporate income tax code.   For Allianz's banking operations, of which Dresdner Bank contributes around 96%, analysts expect improvements on the operating level and higher trading profit to result in a rise in operating profits. Meanwhile, higher restructuring costs and loan-loss provisions are expected to curb net profits.   "We expect some seasonal deterioration in Dresdner's cost/income ratio and a small rise from its recent low bad-debt levels, although the full-year results should remain well ahead of last year's performance," Lehman Bros. analysts wrote who rate the shares at overweight.   On average, the analysts surveyed expect Allianz's banking operations to book a quarterly operating profit of EUR298 million, up from EUR10 million in the fourth quarter of 2005, and a net profit of EUR9 million, down from  EUR83 million.   For the full year, net profit of the banking operations is expected to rise 6% to EUR1.1 billion from EUR1.0 billion, and operating profit is seen improving to EUR1.57 billion from EUR705 million.   Allianz has said that up to EUR350 million could arise in restructuring costs for Dresdner Bank in the fourth quarter.   It also said in August that the bank's bad-debt provisions for the second half would amount to EUR200 million gross.   In 2005, both the bank's quarterly and full-year earnings benefited from net releases of EUR21 million and EUR110 million, respectively, in provisions the bank had made for expected non-performing loans.   Investors are waiting for Allianz to comment Thursday on the group's planned dividend payment for 2006 and on its pledge to gradually increase the dividend payout ratio in coming years.   "We would be disappointed if the (2006) dividend were less than EUR3.20 (a share) and would not be completely surprised it reached EUR3.50," Fox-Pitt, Kelton analysts wrote who rate the share at in-line. For 2005, the dividend was EUR2 a share.   Investors also expect fresh earnings targets for 2007 and 2008, and more details about the financing of the minority buyouts of French Assurances Generales de France SA (12592.FR) and of Germany's Allianz Lebensversicherungs-AG (ALL.XE), both announced in January.   At 1138 GMT, Allianz shares were flat at EUR155.63, slightly underperforming the DAX, which was up 0.5%.   Company Web site: http://www.allianz.com   -By Ulrike Dauer, Dow Jones Newswires; +49 69 29725 500; ulrike.dauer@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 06:40 ET (11:40 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Areva Studying An Uranium Field In Niger - Newspaper
Story: PARIS (Dow Jones)--French Nuclear power group Areva (427583.FR) is studying an area in Northern Niger looking for a potentially rich uranium field, the French weekly La Lettre de l'Expansion reported on Monday, without citing sources.   Areva could also launch a plan to upgrade its two local facilities, left out because of low uranium prices, La Lettre de l'Expansion also reported.   Newspaper Web site:http://www.lexpansion.com     -By Paris Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; 33-1-4017 1740     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 01:51 ET (06:51 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Danisco Ruled Liable To Pay $8.2M In Damages To Novozymes
Story: By DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   A court in the U.S. city of Delaware has ruled Danish sugar and enzyme company Danisco A/S (DCO.KO) liable to pay damages totalling $8.2 million to peer Novozymes A/S (NVZMY) for infringing an enzyme patent, Danisco said Monday.   Danisco said the ruling also involves paying interest and a share of the legal fees of Denmark-headquartered Novozymes.   Either party may appeal within 30 days after the final judgment is entered by the court.   Danisco said it will now assess the legal reasoning of the decisions with regard to the question of liability and damages.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 03:21 ET (08:21 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Regulator Seeks Alfa Mandatory Offer For Turkcell Shrs-IHA-3
Story: Further legal tussles could lie ahead. In a separate case, Nordic telecommunications firm TeliaSonera (TLSN.SK), another major shareholder in Turkcell Iletisim with 13%, has taken legal action against Alfa and Cukurova for the control of Turkcell Iletisim.   In March 2005, debt-laden Turkish group Cukurova Holding had agreed to sell all its shares in Turkcell Iletisim to TeliaSonera for $3.1 billion.   But this was derailed by the Alfa Group and its $3.3-billion loan package for Cukurova in return for sharing the control of Turkcell Iletisim. Cukurova decided to cancel its agreement with TeliaSonera and signed a new agreement with Alfa.   But at the start of this year an international arbitration court ruled that Cukurova has to comply with its original agreement with TeliaSonera.   Some analysts say, Alfa does not want to be obliged to buy the remaining shares of the minority shareholders and is more likely to reach an agreement with TeliaSonera for sharing control of Turkcell Iletisim or get out of the deal completely.   Last week, Russian press reports said that Alfa Group's telecoms arm Altimo might swap its shares in Russian mobile phone group MegaFon and Turkcell Iletisim for a minority stake in TeliaSonera.   Turkcell Iletisim is currently controlled by Turkcell Holding AS, which is 51% owned by Cukurova Holding; 23.4% of the company is traded on the stock exchange.   TeliaSonera owns 43.7% of MegaFon. The Nordic telecoms company said last week that it aims to gain control of both Turkcell Iletisim and MegaFon or would sell its stakes. Altimo also controls 25.1% of MegaFon.     Agency Web sites: www.iha.com.tr; www.ihavideo.net     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 06:41 ET (11:41 GMT)

Headline: : Primary Energy Recycling Corporation Announces February Distribution
Story: OAK BROOK, IL, Feb. 19 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ - Primary Energy Recycling Corporation (TSX: PRI.UN) announced today that a cash distribution of Cdn$ 0.0959 per enhanced income security ("EIS") of the Issuer will be paid on March 30, 2007 to holders of record on February 28, 2007.     Each EIS consists of one common share of the Issuer (a "Common Share") and Cdn$ 2.50 principal amount of 11.75% subordinated note of the Issuer (the "Subordinated Note"). The EISs trade on the Toronto Stock Exchange under the symbol PRI.UN. The total distribution of Cdn$ 0.0959 per EIS reflects a cash distribution of Cdn$ 0.0714 per Common Share and an interest payment of Cdn$ 0.0245 per Cdn$ 2.50 principal amount of Subordinated Note for the period from February 1 to February 28, 2007.     The Issuer owns a majority interest in Primary Energy Recycling Holdings LLC ("Primary Energy"). Primary Energy, headquartered in Oak Brook, Illinois, indirectly owns and operates four recycled energy projects and a 50% interest in a pulverized coal facility (collectively, the "Projects"). The Projects have a combined electrical generating capacity of 283 megawatts and a combined steam generating capacity of 1,851 Mlbs/hour. Primary Energy creates value for its customers by capturing and recycling waste energy from industrial and electric generation processes and converting it into reliable and economical electricity and thermal energy for its customers' use. For more information, please visit us at www.primaryenergyrecycling.com.    SOURCE  Primary Energy Recycling Corporation       /CONTACT: Mark C. Hall, Senior Vice President, Primary Energy Ventures, (630) 371-0573, investorinfo@primaryenergy.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 17:18 ET (22:18 GMT)

Headline: : OMI Corporation Reports 2006 -2-
Story: The tanker market continued to operate at a very profitable level in the fourth quarter of 2006, notwithstanding an increase in the world tanker fleet. However, the average spot TCE rate for Suezmax tankers in the West Africa to U.S. trade was lower than the preceding quarter and the rate prevailing in the same period of last year. This was the result of weaker oil demand growth, because of warm winter weather in the Northern hemisphere, and relatively high oil inventories which resulted in falling oil prices and oil production cuts by OPEC. Freight rates in the crude oil tanker market have continued at high levels thus far in the first quarter of 2007.     The average OPEC oil production in the fourth quarter of 2006 totaled about 29.4 million barrels per day ("b/d"), about 0.8 million b/d lower compared to the preceding quarter and 0.4 million b/d below the level prevailing in the same quarter of last year. Almost all of the sequential quarterly decrease was from the long haul Middle East. This was due to OPEC's successful agreement to cut its oil production by 1.2 million b/d beginning on November 1, 2006, in an attempt to reverse a decrease in oil prices. Subsequently, OPEC has agreed to lower its oil production by an additional 0.5 million b/d from February 1, 2007.     World oil demand in the fourth quarter of 2006 was about 1.0 million b/d higher than the preceding quarter and averaged 1.1 million b/d higher compared to the same period of last year. World oil demand in 2006 was about 0.8 million b/d, or 1.0% higher than in 2005. The moderate world oil demand growth in 2006 was the result of high average oil prices due to low spare oil production capacity and on-going geopolitical risks.     Total preliminary commercial crude oil and petroleum products inventories in the United States, Western Europe and Japan at the end of 2006 were about 35 million barrels, or 1.6% higher than the year earlier level, and 3.5% above the average of the last five years. At the same time, crude oil inventories were 4.0% and petroleum products inventories were 3.3% higher than the average of the last five years, respectively.     The world tanker fleet totaled 345.4 million dwt at the end of 2006, up by about 20.4 million dwt or 6.3% from the year-end 2005 level. The total tanker fleet includes 45.8 million dwt Suezmaxes, excluding shuttle and U.S. flag Suezmaxes, up by 7.5% from the year-end 2005 level.     The tanker orderbook totaled about 129.0 million dwt, or 37.3% of the existing fleet at the end of 2006. Approximately 30.7 million dwt are for delivery in 2007, 35.3 million dwt in 2008, 45.6 million dwt in 2009, and most of the balance in 2010. The tanker orderbook includes 123 Suezmaxes of about 19.5 million dwt or 42.6% of the existing internationally trading Suezmax tanker fleet. Twenty-five Suezmaxes are for delivery in 2007, 22 in 2008, 61 in 2009 and the balance in 2010.     At the end of 2006, approximately 30.4 million dwt or 8.8% of the total tanker fleet was 20 or more years old, including 9.9 million dwt or 2.9% of the fleet which was 25 or more years old. Furthermore, six Suezmaxes were 20 or more years old, including one which was 25 or more years old. Tanker sales for scrap and for Floating Production Storage Offloading ("FPSO") and heavy-lift vessel conversion totaled about 5.1 million dwt in 2006, including four VLCCs and nine Suezmaxes of which three were U.S. flag and two were shuttle tankers.     The EU adopted tanker regulations which commenced on October 21, 2003. In response to the EU regulations, the IMO adopted new strict tanker regulations which commenced on April 5, 2005. At the end of 2006, there were about 91.7 million dwt of tankers or 26.5% of the total tanker fleet which will be affected by these regulations.       Product Tanker Overview     Freight rates in the product tanker market continued at high levels in the fourth quarter of 2006, though the average spot TCE for handysize product tankers in the Caribbean was below the preceding quarter rate and the rate prevailing in the same period of last year. The product tanker market strength was the result of continuous growth in the demand for oil and shortage of refinery capacity in consuming areas, notwithstanding an increase of the world product tanker fleet. Freight rates in the product tanker market have continued at high levels thus far in the first quarter of 2007.     The world product tanker fleet, (which ranges from small 10,000 dwt product carriers to larger than 100,000 dwt for coated Aframax tankers) totaled about 83.2 million dwt at the end of 2006, up by about 10.9% from the year-end 2005 level. The total product tanker fleet includes about 45.7 million dwt handysize and handymax product tankers, up by 8.6% from the year-end 2005 level.     The product tanker orderbook for delivery over the next few years totaled about 40.5 million dwt, or about 48.7% of the existing product tanker fleet at the end of 2006. Approximately 12.6 million dwt are for delivery in 2007, 13.1 million dwt in 2008 and most of the balance in 2009. At the end of 2006, approximately 13.4 million dwt or 16.1% of the existing fleet was 20 or more years old.     The orderbook for handysize and handymax product tankers at the end of 2006 totaled about 15.0 million dwt or 32.8% of the existing handysize and handymax product tanker fleet. Approximately 5.7 million dwt are for delivery in 2007, 5.2 million dwt in 2008 and most of the balance in 2009.     Total preliminary commercial inventories of oil products in the United States, Western Europe and Japan at the end of 2006 were 43 million barrels or 3.1% higher than the same time a year ago, and 3.3% above the average of the last five years. At the same time, inventories of middle distillates, the seasonal product, in these areas were 3.1% and 4.7% higher than last year and the last five years average, respectively.       FLEET SUMMARY     Our fleet is concentrated into two vessel types: Suezmax tankers ("crude" vessels), which generally carry crude oil from areas of oil production to refinery areas, and product carriers ("clean" vessels), which generally carry refined petroleum products (such as gasoline and aviation fuel) from refineries to distribution areas. At December 31, 2006, our fleet comprised 46 vessels, including the ASHLEY which was sold in February and the SEINE, which is scheduled to be delivered in March 2007 and excluding the vessels from the other participants in our wholly owned Gemini and Libra Pools. We charter-in 9 vessels, 6 Suezmax tankers and 3 product carriers (See Exhibit 1 for OMI's Fleet Report by vessel).     The following table of OMI's fleet includes wholly owned and chartered-in vessels at December 31, 2006 and revenue days for the fourth quarter:                                                                     Total               Number    Number   Number of   Number    Total    Number                  of      of        Vessels      of     Number     of                Vessels   Revenue  Chartered-  Revenue    of     Revenue                 Owned    Days         In       Days    Vessels   Days               -------- --------- ----------- -------- -------- --------  Suezmaxes -   Spot(a),(b)       4       365           3      275        7      640  Suezmaxes -   TC(c)             3       276           3      276        6      552  Product   Carriers -   Spot(d)           2       304           1       43        3      347  Product   Carriers -   TC               28     2,503           2      184       30    2,687               -------- --------- ----------- -------- -------- --------  Total             37     3,448           9      778       46    4,226               -------- --------- ----------- -------- -------- --------    (a) Excludes 7 vessels owned by other pool participants that operate   in the Gemini Suezmax Pool. Headline: UPDATE: UK Police Arrest Man Over Letter Bomb Attacks
Story: (Updates an item published at 1029 GMT with details of arrest, forensic search, previous detention of a suspect)   LONDON (AP)--Police in the U.K. arrested a man early Monday in connection with a series of letter bombs sent to offices linked to traffic enforcement.   The man was arrested near the city of Cambridge, 55 miles (90 kms) northeast of London, said Anton Setchell, the Association of Chief Police officers' national coordinator for domestic extremism.   The association has taken the lead in the investigation, which includes four earlier cases. Altogether, nine people have been injured in the attacks.   Setchell gave no details about the suspect who was arrested in Cherry Hinton, on the southeast edge of Cambridge.   Forensic teams had begun a search of a residence which was expected to continue for several days, he said.   "At this stage I am not able to guarantee that there is not another postal package containing an explosive device within the postal system," Setchell told a news conference.   On Feb. 5, a woman was injured by an exploding parcel at the head office of Capita Group PLC in London. One of the company's many government contracts is for designing and running a system for enforcing the GBP8 (EUR12, US$16) daily congestion charge imposed on motorists in central London.   Two people were injured Feb. 6 in an explosion at Vantis PLC in Wokingham, 40 miles (65 kilometers) southwest of London. The accounting company reported the package was addressed to a client. Police said the company's clients include Speed Check Services, which provides traffic monitoring technology.   The next day, three people were treated after a parcel bomb exploded at the headquarters of the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency in Swansea, South Wales.   On Feb. 9, police detained a man who telephoned a radio talk show, claiming he had sent the devices. He was detained under the Mental Health Act.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 19, 2007 06:09 ET (11:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
